After trying unsuccessfully several times to enter, Elisa sings this aria, calling Agenor cruel and asking how he can keep her parted from her beloved.  She then goes on to appeal to his compassion by asking him why he does not pity her state.  After all, she says, doesn't he have a heart?

In his aria, Alexander compares the war and violence to storms and lightning saying that, while they do damage initially, the rain they provide nourishes the soil in the long run.

title: Per me rispondete

He responds with this aria, which is Agenor's plea to the stars of love to show her how much he loves her.  They have known all the ways of his heart ever since they captured him in the first place.

He, of course, doesn't know of any of the other characters' respective loves and Agenor is too obedient to bring it up.  He believes that he has made everyone happy and he expresses these feelings in this aria, singing that if he leaves only peace and happiness behind him, he has fulfilled all of his wishes.

subtitle: - No. 6 from the one-act Italian opera, Il Sogno di Scipione (The Dream of Scipione) by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

range: E3 to A5. Tessitura G3 to G4

subtitle: - No. 7 from the one-act Italian opera, Il Sogno di Scipione (The Dream of Scipione) by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

range: E4 to A6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to F#/Gb5

title: Lorsque l'enfant revient d'un voyage

libretto: Edouard Blau and Paul Milliet and Georges Hartmann

range: C4 to F#/Gb5. Tessitura F4 to F5
synopsis: Charlotte reads Werther's letters to her which tell her of his sorrow and of his happiness when they will be together.  His emotions make her realize that she still loves him.

title: Ruhe sanft, mein holdes Leben

setting: under a tree
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Zaide comes upon Gomatz sleeping under a tree.  She admires his good looks and leaves him jewels, money, a portrait of her and a letter asking him to meet her later in that same spot.  She then sings that he should sleep until he awakes with happiness.  She hopes that her tears will bring his wishes to reality.

title: Trostlos schluchzet Philomele
subtitle: from Act II of the German opera, Zaide by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: most likely a dungeon although it is not certain
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: In this aria, Zaide compares herself to a nightingale who is trapped in a cage like she has been imprisoned in the dungeon.  It cries out continually for its loss of freedom and is always looking for some way to escape just as she does.

subtitle: from Act II of the German opera, Zaide by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: most likely a dungeon, although it is not certain
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Zaide becomes defiant and asks the "tiger", which really represents the Sultan, to come and kill them quickly.  She cries out that fate has no mercy on her and that only death will ease her distress.

setting: under a tree
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Gomatz awakes to find a purse, a portrait of a woman and a letter from the woman next to him.  He falls immediately in love with the woman and declares that his cruel destiny cannot touch him anymore, especially not with this woman's beautiful  visage to help him.

synopsis: Allazim, Gomatz's overseer, has overheard Gomatz and Zaide profess their love to one another.  He confronts Gomatz and reminds him that he can punish escape, which Zaide suggested, by instant execution.  He likes Gomatz, though, and promises to help them if Zaide proves to be faithful.  Gomatz responds with this aria.  He thanks Allazim profusely and offers to kiss and embrace him.  He also mentions that he has no idea what he is doing because his love has overwhelmed him.

title: Der stolze Lw' lsst sich zwar zhmen
subtitle: from Act II of the German opera, Zaide by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: most likely in the palace of the Sultan
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Zaide has escaped along with Gomatz and Allazim and the Sultan is enraged over this.  He compares himself to a lion who trusts his underlings, but  when betrayed by them, becomes violent and goes after them with a vengence.

title: Ich bin so bs als gut
subtitle: from Act II of the German opera, Zaide by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: the  palace of the Sultan
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: The king sings that he is as bad as he is good and that, while he will reward good service, he is ready to punish any that betray him.  He is most likely singing to Allazim, who has been captured along with Zaide and Gomatz.

title: Nur mutig, mein Herze
subtitle: from Act I of the German opera, Zaide by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: under a tree
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Although it is not sure what the exact circumstances this aria takes place under, it is suggested that Allazim is planning to escape when Zaide and Gomatz attempt to escape.  In the aria, he tries to convince himself that he can escape if he only has courage.

title: Wer hungrig bei der Tafel sitzt

synopsis: The situation that this comic aria is sung in is not certain, since the rest of the libretto is not extant, but the aria is most likely advice given to the Sultan.  Osmin sings that a man who looks for what he already has is a fool just like a man who sits a table full of food and complains of hunger.

range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Allazim is pleading with the Sultan to spare the lives of Gomatz and Zaide, saying that masters treat their slaves as inferior and don't recognize them as the human beings they are.  He then goes on to say that other people's suffering can only be understood by the compassionate man.

Tebaldo agrees, saying that Capellio's vendetta will be discharged by his love for Giulietta which everyone knows about.  Love is more dear to him than the sun that shines.  To him, every joy lives only in Giulietta.

title: Se Romeo l'uccise un figlio

If he is allowed to marry Giulietta, Capellio will have another son in Romeo.

title: Eccomi in lieta vestaOh quante volte ti chiedo

subtitle: from Act II of the Italian opera, I Capuleti ed i Montecchi by Vincenzo Bellini

range: E4 to A6. Tessitura Has not been entered yet.

synopsis: Jacopo has been exiled from Venice and has now been brought before the Venetian Council of Ten (headed by his father) to face charges of murder.  He sings of Venice and how he missed it in his exile.

setting: A hall in the Foscari palace, Venice, 1457

Assured that he will be presented with a easy sentence, he explodes into this cabaletta, singing his defiance and claiming that he is innocent and that he is only being kept by their hate for him.

title: Tu al cui sguardi onni possente

Angry at this sort of mercy that seems very unmerciful to her, Lucrezia's cabaletta is focused on her thoughts on the Council's sort of "mercy".

title: O vecchio cor che batte

Finally, as the ghost continues to come nearer, Jacopo faints.

title: Quel bronzo feral

Giving over his ring and crown signifying his office, Francesco sings that he feels that he is already dying and, as the accompaniment to the cabaletta is ending, he collapses, crying out "My son...", and dies.

title: Sento Iddio che mi chiama

After being told that the Council will be lenient in its sentencing of him, Jacopo sings that he cannot do anything but put his trust into God to have mercy upon him.

Arvino enters and adds that he has heard some strange noises in the palace and that he is going to investigate.  Giselda then sings this prayer to God as her mother wants.

setting: The hall of Lammermoor Castle
range: Has not been entered yet.

range: Has not been entered yet.

subtitle: from Act III, Scene I of the Italian opera, Lucia di Lammermoor by Gaetano Donizetti

range: Has not been entered yet.

title: Vieni ov'amor t'invita
subtitle: - No. 1 from Act I of the Italian opera, Lucio Silla by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

Cecilius cannot go save her or he too will be killed.  In his aria, though, Cinna expressed his optimism, saying that Cecilius should go where love wants him to.  Cinna is already able to feel that everything will turn out all right.  Like the sea, when life is rough it eventually gets better.

title: Il tenero momento
subtitle: - No. 2 from Act I of the Italian opera, Lucio Silla by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: the banks of the Tiber in a grove near ruins
range: Has not been entered yet.

He sings in his aria that he can already imagine the moment he sees his wife again.  He wonders though how much joy he will feel if now, when he is only thinking about her, he feels exhilirated.

title: Se lusinghiera speme

range: Has not been entered yet.

After all, as she sings in her aria, even the most stubborn woman will eventually give in to flattery and gentleness.

title: Dalla sponda tenebrosa
subtitle: - No. 4 from Act I of the Italian opera, Lucio Silla by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

synopsis: After Junia expresses her hatred for Sulla, Sulla gives her a choice love him or die.  She is furious that he thinks that she will compromise her love to stay alive.  In her aria, she calls to her father and her husband to receive her into the land of death.  She then continues on to rage against Sulla and to say that she will be happy when she is dead and he feels guilty for killing her.

title: Quest' improvviso tremito
subtitle: - No. 9 from Act II of the Italian opera, Lucio Silla by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Cecilius appears with a sword to go after Sulla and Cinna tries to restrain him.  When Cinna asks him why he is doing it, Cecilius responds that Junia's father came to him in a dream and demanded that he kill Sulla at once.  He then launches into his aria saying that the sudden trembling he feels in his chest could be anger or it could be hope.  Whatever it is, though, it will go after Sulla with a vengence.

subtitle: - No. 4, Cavatina from Act I of the Italian opera, Maria Stuarda by Gaetano Donizetti
setting: the Palace of Westminster, London, England, 1567
range: G3 to A5. Tessitura B4 to A5
synopsis: Talbot, the Earl of Shrewsbury, has visited Maria Stuarda where she is imprisoned at Fotheringay Castle.  He tells Leicester that Maria Stuarda has asked for him specifically to help her.  Leicester is struck with the beauty of Maria's portrait, and rhapsodizes on her beauty.

title: Oh nube! che lieve per l'aria ti aggiri...Nella pace del mesto riposo
subtitle: - No. 6, Cavatina and cabaletta from Act II of the Italian opera, Maria Stuarda by Gaetano Donizetti
setting: the Park at Fotheringay Castle, Northamptonshire, England, 1567
range: G#/Ab3 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: Imprisoned at the castle with her companion Anna, Maria sings about the happy times she had when she lived at the French court far from the power struggles between England and Scotland.  She then hears the approach of the Queen's party and realizes that the meeting with her love Leicester will soon happen.  While she has been looking forward to this, she also worries that her affection will not be returned.

title: Deh! tu di un umile preghiera
subtitle: - No. 17, Preghiera degli Scozzesi from Act III, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Maria Stuarda by Gaetano Donizetti
setting: Fotheringay Castle, Northamptonshire, England, 1567
range: D#/Eb4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura A#/Bb5 to G5
synopsis: Awaiting her execution, Maria prays to God with her supporters, asking him for forgiveness.

title: Di un cor che more
subtitle: - part of No. 18, Aria del supplizio from Act III, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Maria Stuarda by Gaetano Donizetti
setting: Fotheringay Castle, Northamptonshire, England, 1567
range: C4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura G#/Ab4 to G5
synopsis: Awaiting her execution, Maria seems to accept her fate.  She hopes that with her death, all the strife that has occurred will cease.

title: Ah! se un giorno da queste ritorte
subtitle: - part of No. 18, Aria del supplizio from Act III, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Maria Stuarda by Gaetano Donizetti
setting: Fotheringay Castle, Northamptonshire, England, 1567
range: D4 to B6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Maria Stuarda is about to be executed.  Just before the execution, her fiancee, the Earl of Leicester appears to say goodbye.  Spurred by this show of affection, Maria cries out her innocence once more and calls out for God to punish those who have falsely accused her.

title: Quella vita a me funesta
subtitle: - part of No. 12, Duettino from Act III, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Maria Stuarda by Gaetano Donizetti
setting: the Palace of Westminster, London, England, 1567
range: D4 to G#/Ab5. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Maria Stuarda, the Queen of Scots, has insulted Queen Elisabetta while imprisoned in England.  Furious, Elisabetta has sentenced her to death.  Now, she waits with Lord Burleigh to sign the warrant that will allow the execution of her rival in both power and love.   She contemplates her power over the life and death of Maria Stuarda, wondering if she is making the correct decision.

title: Die letzte Rose (Wui sola, vergin rosa)
subtitle: - No. 9, Romanze from Act II of the Italian|German opera, Martha by Friedrich von Flotow
role: Lady Harriet Durham (Martha),  The Maid-Of-Honor to Queen Anne
setting: Plunkett's farm, the town of Richmond, England, 18th century during the reign of Queen Anne
range: F4 to F5. Tessitura F4 to F5
synopsis: Disguised as Martha, Harriet has been taken to Plunkett's farmhouse along with Nancy (who is disguised as Julia) in order to do their housework.  However, they have no idea how to do anything.   After Nancy knocks over Plunkett's spinning wheel and is chased away by him, Harriet and Lionel are left alone.  Lionel declares that he has fallen in love with Harriet and asks her to sing a folk song.  She responds with the Irish song "The Last Rose of Summer".

title: Lasst mich euch fragen (Chi mi dira)
subtitle: - No. 12, Lied with Chorus from Act III of the Italian|German opera, Martha by Friedrich von Flotow
setting: An inn in Richmond, England, 18th century during the reign of Queen Anne
range: G2 to F4. Tessitura C3 to C4
synopsis: As Plunkett drinks beer with his farmer friends, he sings a drinking song praising the qualities of English ale.

title: Jgerin, schlau im Sinn
subtitle: - No. 14, Lied with Chorus from Act III of the German opera, Martha by Friedrich von Flotow
role: Nancy (Julia),  Lady Harriet's friend and maid
setting: A hunting park in Richmond Forest, England, 18th century during the reign of Queen Anne
range: C4 to A6. Tessitura E4 to D5
synopsis: Along with the ladies-in-waiting, Nancy sings a hunting song.

title: Ach so fromm, ach so traut (M'appari)
subtitle: - No. 15, Lied from Act III of the Italian|German opera, Martha by Friedrich von Flotow
setting: A hunting park in Richmond Forest, England, 18th century during the reign of Queen Anne
range: G3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura A4 to G4
synopsis: After meeting Lady Harriet the night before disguised as "Martha", Lionel sees her again with the ladies-in-waiting for Queen Anne.  He is struck again by her beauty and grieves that he will probably never be with her again.

title: Den Theuren zu vershnen
subtitle: - No. 18 from Act IV of the German opera, Martha by Friedrich von Flotow
role: Lady Harriet Durham (Martha),  The Maid-Of-Honor to Queen Anne
setting: Plunkett's farm, the town of Richmond, England, 18th century during the reign of Queen Anne
range: A#/Bb4 to D6. Tessitura E4 to F5
synopsis: After sending Nancy to bring Lionel to her, Harriet declares that she will tell Lionel that she loves him and then they will both be happy.

title: Nimmermehr wird mein Herze, (Esser mesto il mio cor)
subtitle: - later addition to the opera from Act III of the Italian|German opera, Martha by Friedrich von Flotow
role: Nancy (Julia),  Lady Harriet's friend and maid
setting: A hunting park in Richmond Forest, England, 18th century during the reign of Queen Anne
range: G#/Ab3 to B6. Tessitura F4 to F5
synopsis: This aria extends "Jgerin, schlau im Sinn" into an entire aria for Nancy.  It declares the love that Nancy feels for the farmer Plunkett.  It was written originally for  Mmme. Nantier-Didie.

title: Ave, Signor
subtitle: from Prologue of the Italian opera, Mefistofele by Arrigo Boito
setting: The Heavens
range: A#/Bb3 to F4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Mefistofele speaks to God and offers to wager that he can win the soul of Doctor Faust, a respected philosopher, by enticing him to sin.

title: Dai campi, dai prati
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Mefistofele by Arrigo Boito
setting: Faust's study, Frankfurt, Germany, medievel times
range: F3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura A4 to G4
synopsis: It is Easter.  Faust sings of the eternal peace and goodness of the world.

title: Son lo spirito che nega sempre (Whistle Aria)
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Mefistofele by Arrigo Boito
setting: Faust's study, Frankfurt, Germany, medievel times
range: G2 to E4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Mefistofele reveals his true nature to Faust and goes on to describe his evil features.

title: Colma il tuo coro d'un palpito
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Mefistofele by Arrigo Boito
setting: Margherita's garden, Frankfurt, Germany, medieval times
range: E3 to B5. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: Faust has been rejuvenated by the Devil and now is wooing Margherita with a passionate song

title: Ecco il mondo
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Mefistofele by Arrigo Boito
setting: The heights of Brocken Mountain, medieval times
range: A#/Bb3 to F4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: During a series of Satanic rituals on the mountaintop, a group of witches give Mefistofele a glass globe.  He sees the world in it and declares his hatred for it.

title: L'altra notte in fondo al mare
subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, Mefistofele by Arrigo Boito
setting: Margherita's prison cell, Germany, medieval times
range: D4 to B6. Tessitura E4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Margherita has poisoned her mother and killed her illegitimate baby and now has been imprisoned.  She sings of her insanity and her coming execution.

title: Spunta l'aurora pallida
subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, Mefistofele by Arrigo Boito
setting: Margherita's prison cell, Germany, medieval times
range: F4 to B6. Tessitura G#/Ab4 to F5
synopsis: Margherita is awaiting execution.  She realizes that her only recourse left to her is God.  She prays to him, asking him to forgive all of the errors and sins of her past.

title: Forma ideal purissima
subtitle: from Act IV of the Italian opera, Mefistofele by Arrigo Boito
setting: Ancient Greece
range: F3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura F3 to F4
synopsis: Mefistofele takes Faust back to Ancient Greece and introduces him to Helen of Troy in order to convince him to give in to sin.  Faust finds that Helen is his ideal woman in beauty and purity and tells her this.

title: Se vano  il pregare...No giusta causa non  d'Iddio
subtitle: from Part II : The Man of the Cave, Scene III of the Italian opera, I Lombardi alla Prima Crociata by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Giselda,  daughter of Arvino and Viclinda
setting: the Harem of Antioch
range: D4 to C#/Db6. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to B6
synopsis: Giselda is in captivity and she has fallen in love with Oronte, a man who is not only her abductor's son but also is not even Christian.  Thus, in the first part of the aria, she prays to her mother's spirit to help her since she should not be loving this non-Christian.  After this, screams are heard from outside and the harem runs by her.  Sofia is with them and stops just long enough to say that her husband and son have been killed by the Crusaders who have invaded the palace.  As she runs out, Arvino and Pagano walk in.  Giselda then begins her cabaletta, singing furiously that the crusade will never succeed.  She foretells disaster and destruction for the crusaders and finishes by singing "Dio non lo vuole" or "God does not want it (the crusade)".

title: Non fu sogno
subtitle: from Part IV : The Holy Sepulchre, Scene I of the Italian opera, I Lombardi alla Prima Crociata by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Giselda,  daughter of Arvino and Viclinda
setting: a cave near Jerusalem
range: E4 to C6. Tessitura F4 to A6
synopsis: After Oronte has come to her as an angel and told her where water can be found to relieve the Crusaders' lack of water, Giselda sings this aria to express her news both at knowing where water is to be found and at hearing her beloved once again.

title: La mia letizia infondere...Come poteva un angelo
subtitle: - Cavatina and Cabaletta from Part II : The Man of the Cave, Scene I of the Italian opera, I Lombardi alla Prima Crociata by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: a hall in Acciano's palace
range: E3 to A5. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Giselda, Arvino's daughter, has fallen into the hands of her father's enemy, Acciano.  Oronte sees her and they fall in love with each other.  He proceeds to lay out all his feelings for her in the first part of his aria.  After he is warned by his mother that he will only be able to have her if he becomes a Christian, he states that he will become Christian for, as he sings in the cabaletta, if she believes in this god, he must he the true one.  To him, she seems like an angel of purity and virtue.

title: In cielo benedetto
subtitle: from Part IV : The Holy Sepulchre, Scene I of the Italian opera, I Lombardi alla Prima Crociata by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: a cave near Jerusalem
range: F3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Oronte has been killed by Arvino's men in Part III.  He returns, though, in Part IV as an angel sitting on a cloud and sings this aria to Giselda who has fallen unconscious and needs water.  The only purpose of the aria is to tell her that the Crusaders can find water in Siloim.

title: Sciagurata, ed hai creduto...O speranza di vendetta
subtitle: - Aria and Cabaletta from Part I : The Vendetta, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, I Lombardi alla Prima Crociata by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: the square of San Ambrogio
range: C3 to F4. Tessitura D3 to F4
synopsis: After returning from his exile for killing two of his brother Arvino's men, Pagano tells his squire Pirro that it was not his own evilness that led him to kill the two men.  It was only his grief that Viclinda had chosen his brother instead of him that drove him to these crimes.  He then proceeds to talk to Viclinda as if she were there, saying that it was all because his love for her was refused.  Inbetween the two parts of the aria, men who are going to set fire to Arvino's house come along.  Pagano warns them of the dangers that lie in burning his brother's house, the men respond firmly that will do it.  Pagano then launches into his cabaletta which revels in the joy of the revenge that he will finally have.

title: Ma quando un suon terrible
subtitle: from Part II : The Man of the Cave, Scene II of the Italian opera, I Lombardi alla Prima Crociata by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: the entrance to a cave
range: C3 to D#/Eb4. Tessitura C3 to D4
synopsis: Pagano has become a hermit after mistakenly killing his father.  In this aria, he sings of God's grace and forgiveness his own redemption.

title: O mio castel paterno
subtitle: - Cavatina from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, I Masnadieri by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: the exterior of a tavern in Saxony, Germany, early 18th century
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Carlo thinks of his home and the beautiful forests and green hills surrounding it.  He also thinks longingly of his love, Amalia.

subtitle: - Cabaletta for O mio castel paterno from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, I Masnadieri by Giuseppe Verdi

range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Carlo receives a letter from his brother Francesco warning him not to return to home under threat of imprisonment.  Rolla, Carlo's friend, suggests that he and the rest of Carlo's companions form a bandit company headed by Carlo.  After disagreeing with this suggestion, Carlo accepts this idea and goes on to lead his companions in an oath of allegiance.

title: La sua lampada vitale
subtitle: - Cavatina from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, I Masnadieri by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: a room in the castle of Count Moor, Germany, early 18th century
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Francesco contemplates his father's fraility and plans to "help" nature along in killing his father.

title: Tremate, o miseri
subtitle: - Cabaletta for La sua lampada vitale from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, I Masnadieri by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: a room in the castle of Count Moor, Germany, early 18th century
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After sending Arminio off to tell his frail father that Carlo has died in hopes of causing his father to die from sadness, Francesco gloats over his assured victory, saying that now the people will see the true Francesco.

title: Lo sguardo avea degli angeli
subtitle: - Cavatina from Act I, Scene 3 of the Italian opera, I Masnadieri by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: a bedroom in the castle of Count Moor, Germany, early 18th century
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Amalia watches Massimiliano sleep and relates her sadness for the loss of Carlo's love after he was sent away by Massimiliano.

title: Tu del mio Carlo al seno
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, I Masnadieri by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: the family vault of the Moors, Germany, early 18th century
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: It has been a few months after Francesco has taken over the Moor household after both Massimiliano his father and Carlo his brother have apparantly died.  Amalia is very unhappy with Francesco who  is making her life unbearable and sings of Carlo and Massimiliano who must be reunited in Heaven while she remains allive and unhappy.

title: Carlo vive? O caro accento
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Tu del mio Carlo al seno from Act II, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, I Masnadieri by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: the family vault of the Moors, Germany, early 18th century
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Amalia has just been told that Carlo and Massimiliano are actually alive contrary to news of both of their demises.  Amalia sings her resulting joy from the unexpected and exciting news.

title: Di ladroni attorniato
subtitle: - Romanza from Act II, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, I Masnadieri by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: a forest near Prague, early 18th century
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Carlo is alone watching the sunset.  He laments that he cannot  enjoy the beautiful sight because he has no place on the earth.  His only companions are criminals and he is no better than them in his mind.  He also fondly remembers Amalia, the love he left behind when he was forced to leave his castle by his father and brother.

title: Un ignoto tre lune or saranno
subtitle: - Narrative aria from Act III, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, I Masnadieri by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: nearby a ruin of a keep, Germany, early 18th century
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After returning from exile, Carlo finds his father Massimiliano locked in the dungeone of an abandoned castle.  He asks him who imprisoned him there and Massimiliano responds, telling him that his son Francesco locked him up.  He then goes on to tell the entire story, saying that the news of Carlo's death caused him to faint and then woke up in a coffin.  Francesco was very perturbed to find him still alive and in his desire to get rid of him, threw him into the dungeon.

title: Pareami che sorto da lanto convito
subtitle: - Narrative aria from Act IV, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, I Masnadieri by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: a gallery in the castle of Count Moor, Germany, early 18th century
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Francesco imagines Judgement Day and the terror it will bring.  He imagines that he will not be allowed into Heaven because of his cruel deeds.

title: Si puo?
subtitle: - Prologue from Prologue of the Italian opera, I Pagliacci by Ruggiero Leoncavallo

synopsis: Tonio steps out in front of the curtain apparently in the middle of the overture to explain why the composer wrote the opera as he did.  He then goes on to say that the story that the audience is viewing is not merely a play, but a real story with actors that have real feelings.

title: Un tal gioco, credete mi
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, I Pagliacci by Ruggiero Leoncavallo

setting: The entrance to a village, Calabria, Italy, 1860s
range: D3 to A5. Tessitura F3 to G4
synopsis: After a villager makes a joke about flirting with Canio's wife Nedda, Canio warns the rest of the villagers, saying that while everything on the stage is an illusion, life is reality and with a real transgression comes real punishment.

title: Qual fiamma avea nel guardo
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, I Pagliacci by Ruggiero Leoncavallo
role: Nedda,  Canio's wife (Columbine in the play)
setting: The entrance to a village, Calabria, Italy, 1860s
range: D4 to A6. Tessitura E4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Nedda worries about the jealousy that Canio is showing towards her.  She is afraid that he will find out the truth she has fallen in love with another and has been seeing him behind Canio's back.

title: Stridono lass
subtitle: - Ballatella from Act I of the Italian opera, I Pagliacci by Ruggiero Leoncavallo
role: Nedda,  Canio's wife (Columbine in the play)

title: Alla vita che t'arride

title: Eri tu che macchiavi quell'anima
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Un Ballo in Maschera by Giuseppe Verdi

title: Volta la terrea
subtitle: - Ballata from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Un Ballo in Maschera by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A hall in the Governor's house, Boston, late 17th century.
range: D4 to C6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: Riccardo has been given a paper to sign which will exile Ulrica because of witchcraft.  Oscar speaks up in defense of the fortune teller Ulrica.

title: Grave a core innamorato...Se dee cader la vedova
subtitle: from Act I, Scene I of the Italian opera, Un Giorno di Regno by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Marchesa del Poggio,  the Baron's niece and a widow
setting: the house of Baron Kelbar
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After observing an exchange between Belfiore and Edoardo in which Edoardo asks Belfiore to take him into his army so he may forget his love Giulietta who is promised to his uncle.  The Marchesa knows that one of the two is Belfiore but she is not sure which one since Belfiore is disguised as the king of Poland.  She resolves to pretend to marry Count Ivrea in hopes that Belfiore will reveal himself.  She knows that she will never love anyone but Belfiore so if he betrays her, then she will swear off love for the rest of her life.

title: Si mostri a chi l'adora...Si, scordar sapr l'infido
subtitle: from Act II, Scene II of the Italian opera, Un Giorno di Regno by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Marchesa del Poggio,  the Baron's niece and a widow
setting: a terrance facing Baron Kelbar's gardens
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: The  Marchesa knows that the supposed king of Poland is really Belfiore, her lover.  She attempts to make him reveal himself by threatening to marry Count Ivrea.  When she tells the "king" this in front of the Baron and others, he asks what she would do about Belfiore (i.e. himself).  After all, the "king" points out, Belfiore is sure to try to stop the marriage somehow.  The Marchesa then asks him why Belfiore hasn't shown up yet and launches in the first part of her aria where she states that she will forgive Belfiore for not showing up sooner but only if he apologizes enough.  He doesn't respond to this though and so when the trumpets sound announcing the entrance of Count Ivrea, she goes right into a more abrasive cabaletta in which she conveys that this is Belfiore's last chance to come out in the open and claim her.

title: Non san quant'io nel petto...Non vo' quel vecchio
subtitle: from Act I, Scene II of the Italian opera, Un Giorno di Regno by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Giulietta di Kelbar,  daughter of the Baron
setting: The gardens of Baron Kelbar
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: In the first part of this aria, Giulietta sings about the sorrow she feels because she has to marry Edoardo's uncle, Signor la Rocca.  In the cabaletta that follows, Giulietta is more emphatic about that lack of desire she has to marry La Rocca, who is an old man.

title: Pietoso al lungo pianto...Deh lasciate a un alma amante
subtitle: from Act II, Scene I of the Italian opera, Un Giorno di Regno by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: Baron Kelbar's gallery
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Edoardo, once very worried that his beloved Giulietta would be married to his uncle, now has hope that perhaps he will be able to marry his love after all since his uncle has decided that perhaps someone else might be better.  He tells this all to the servants of the castle (the chorus) in this aria.

title: Compagnoni di Parigi...Verr purtroppo il giorno
subtitle: from Act I, Scene I of the Italian opera, Un Giorno di Regno by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Cavaliere di Belfiore,  pretending to be the king of Poland
setting: the house of Baron Kelbar
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After entering as the king of Poland into Baron Kelbar's court, Belfiore tells the Baron that perhaps he may reward him when he gets back to Poland.  He then tells the audience how pleased he is to be recognized as a king.  Returning his attention to the court, he says that someday the burden of kingship will overwhelm him.

title: Must the winter come so soon?
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 1 of the English opera, Vanessa by Samuel Barber
setting: a drawing room in Vanessa's castle in a northern castle, first decade of the 20 century
range: D#/Eb4 to F5. Tessitura G4 to F5
synopsis: In a question to Vanessa, Erika asks why the winter must be so long and come so soon, bringing with it a gray dreariness  to the forest in which the castle lies.

title: Do not utter a word
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 1 of the English opera, Vanessa by Samuel Barber
role: Vanessa,  a beautiful baroness of a northern country in her late thirties
setting: a drawing room in Vanessa's castle in a northern castle, first decade of the 20 century
range: B4 to B6. Tessitura F4 to A6
synopsis: Anatol has come to Vanessa's castle.  When he enter the room where Vanessa is, she is not facing him.  Believing he is the man who twenty years before left her, she tells him that she has been faithful all through the long wait, always believing that sometime he would return.  She begs him to leave without viewing her face unless he still loves her.

title: Outside this house
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the English opera, Vanessa by Samuel Barber
role: Anatol,  a young man in his twenties
setting: a drawing room in Vanessa's castle in a northern castle, first decade of the 20 century
range: C#/Db3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: After he asks Erika to marry him, Anatol explains to her that he cannot give her eternal love because he does not believe that such love exists.  He still would like to marry her, though, and at least remain friends with her.  He tries to tempt her with the promises of rich living.

title: You rascal you!  I never knew you had a soul
subtitle: from Act II of the English opera, Vanessa by Samuel Barber
role: The Old Doctor,  the doctor of Vanessa's family
setting: the entrance hall of Vanessa's castle on New Year's eve in a northern castle, first decade of the 20 century
range: C#/Db3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura E3 to E4
synopsis: The Doctor is supposed to announce the engagement of Vanessa and Anatol.  However he is very drunk and only wishes to speak of women and their attractiveness under the right circumstances.

title: Why must the greatest sorrows
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 1 of the English opera, Vanessa by Samuel Barber
role: Vanessa,  a beautiful baroness of a northern country in her late thirties
setting: Erika's room in Vanessa's castle in a northern castle, first decade of the 20 century
range: F4 to A6. Tessitura A#/Bb5 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: Erika is missing, having run away earlier.  Frantic with worry, Vanessa wonders why she has gone away and broken her heart in such a manner.

title: On the path to the lake
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 1 of the English opera, Vanessa by Samuel Barber
role: Anatol,  a young man in his twenties
setting: Erika's room in Vanessa's castle in a northern castle, first decade of the 20 century
range: F3 to G4. Tessitura G3 to F4

title: For ev'ry love there is a last farewell
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 2 of the English opera, Vanessa by Samuel Barber

synopsis: Alone, the Doctor thinks of Vanessa.  She is leaving the castle to be married to Anatol and the Doctor, who raised her and cured her illnesses, realizes that he will miss her greatly and wonders if she will miss him.

title: Ah! mon courage m'abandonne
subtitle: from Act III of the French opera, Werther by Jules Massenet
libretto: Edouard Blau and Paul Milliet and Georges Hartmann
setting: the Magistrate's house at Christmas, Frankfurt, Germany, 1780

synopsis: Charlotte has realized that she loves Werther and cannot ever marry him.  She prays to help regain her courage, asking God to have pity on her and hear her plaintive cries.

title: Va! laisse couler mes larmes

libretto: Edouard Blau and Paul Milliet and Georges Hartmann
setting: the Magistrate's house at Christmas, Frankfurt, Germany, 1780
range: C4 to F5. Tessitura D4 to F5
synopsis: Charlotte lets free her sadness that she is not married to Werther and breaks down in tears, saying that her heart is too empty for anything to fill when he is away.

title: Pourquoi me rveiller
subtitle: from Act III of the French opera, Werther by Jules Massenet
libretto: Edouard Blau and Paul Milliet and Georges Hartmann
setting: the Magistrate's house at Christmas, Frankfurt, Germany, 1780
range: F#/Gb3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura G3 to F#/Gb4

One book in particular, Ossain's verses, sparks Werther to ask spring to cease its gentle caresses upon him, for sadness and grief is now his fate.

title: O nature pleine de grce
subtitle: from Act I of the French opera, Werther by Jules Massenet
libretto: Edouard Blau and Paul Milliet and Georges Hartmann
setting: the garden outside the Magistrate's house, Frankfurt, Germany, 1780
range: G3 to A5. Tessitura G3 to F4
synopsis: Werther has come to the Magistrate's house and is enjoying the fresh air, describing the beautiful surroundings he is in.

title: Quelle priere de reconnaissance
subtitle: from Act I of the French opera, Werther by Jules Massenet
libretto: Edouard Blau and Paul Milliet and Georges Hartmann
setting: the garden outside the Magistrate's house, Frankfurt, Germany, 1780
range: D3 to D#/Eb4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Sophie has just told Albert that her father wishes Charlotte and Albert to be married.  He sings of his joy in finding that he will be marrying the one he loves.

role: La Fortuna,  the spirit of Fortune
setting: the temple of Heaven
range: E4 to B6. Tessitura A5 to A6
synopsis: Scipione asks Fortune why he should worship her.  She responds that her favorites receive anything that they want.

title: Biancheggia in mar
subtitle: - No. 9 from the one-act Italian opera, Il Sogno di Scipione (The Dream of Scipione) by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: La Constanza,  the spirit of Constancy
setting: the temple of Heaven
range: D#/Eb4 to C6. Tessitura G4 to A6
synopsis: Scipione asks Constancy why he should worship her.  She responds that her loyalty to her worshipers can withstand many trials, as a large rock on the shoreline can withstand the sea's fury.

title: Di che sei l'arbitra
subtitle: - No. 10 from the one-act Italian opera, Il Sogno di Scipione (The Dream of Scipione) by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: the temple of Heaven
range: D3 to C5. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: After Scipione decides to worship Constancy instead of Fortune, he tells Fortune that it is because she is unforgiving and fickle and only those that have nothing else will worship her.

title: Ah perche cercar degg'io
subtitle: - No. 11 from the one-act Italian opera, Il Sogno di Scipione (The Dream of Scipione) by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: the temple of Heaven
range: E4 to A6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: The Soloist, who represents the "author" of the opera, declares that the audience will learn the lesson of the opera better through observing other human beings rather than watching the opera.

title: ben altro il mio sogno!
subtitle: from the one-act Italian opera, Il Tabarro by Giacomo Puccini

range: E4 to G5. Tessitura F4 to F5
synopsis: Giorgetta asks Michele to leave the life of the barge-owner and settle down to a less abnormal life.

title: Perch, perch non m'ami pi?
subtitle: from the one-act Italian opera, Il Tabarro by Giacomo Puccini
role: Michele,  a barge owner and husband of Giorgetta
setting: A barge on the Seine, Paris, France, 1910
range: D3 to F4. Tessitura E3 to E4
synopsis: Michele asks Giorgetta why she no longer loves him.

subtitle: from the one-act Italian opera, Il Tabarro by Giacomo Puccini

synopsis: After Tinca mentions that he tries to drown his sorrows in large quantities of alcohol, Luigi agrees with him.  Their lives are miserable and there is no hope waiting for them in the future.

title: Di due figli vivea

synopsis: Ferrando entertains a group of soldiers with the story of the Count of Luna's brother, Garcia, who was apparently killed as an infant by the daughter of an old gypsy woman who was burned for being a witch by the Count di Luna's father.

title: Tacea la notte
subtitle: - Cavatina from Act I - The Duel, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi

setting: The gardens of the palace of Aliferia, Aragon, 1409.
range: D4 to C6. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to F5
synopsis: Leonora reveals to her servant Ines that she heard someone serenading her in the garden.  However, when she goes out to see who the troubadour is, she finds that it is, in fact, a knight in black armor who she had once crowned as the champion of a tournament.  She has quickly fallen in love with him.

title: Di tale amor che dirsi
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Tacea la notte from Act I - The Duel, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Leonora,  a lady-in-waiting for the Princess of Aragon

range: G#/Ab3 to C6. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to A#/Bb6
synopsis: Leonora has fallen in love with a knight that serenades her in the gardens at night.   Ines warns her that this troubadour will bring trouble to them all and that Leonora should not continue seeing him.  Leonora responds that she will not stop meeting him, for she would give her life for him.

title: Deserto sulla terra
subtitle: - Romanza from Act I - The Duel, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Manrico,  an officer in Prince Urgel's army and the supposed son of the gypsy woman Azucena
setting: The gardens of the palace of Aliferia, Aragon, 1409.
range: A#/Bb4 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura A#/Bb4 to G4
synopsis: Manrico serenades Leonora, singing that since he has traveled the world alone for so long as a troubadour, he should soon find his love.

title: Stride la vampa!
subtitle: - Canzone from Act II - The Gypsy, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A broken down shack in the Biscay Mountains, 1409.
range: B4 to G5. Tessitura E4 to E5
synopsis: Azucena describes her mother's death to Manrico and the crowd of gypsies.  Her mother was burned on the stake for being a witch while the ones who convicted her falsely laughed and enjoyed themselves.

title: Condotta ell'era in ceppi
subtitle: - Narrative Aria from Act II - The Gypsy, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A broken down shack in the Biscay Mountains, 1409.
range: A4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura E4 to F5
synopsis: Azucena tells Manrico the complete sequence of events that occurred at her mother's execution.  She recounts that, as her mother was being burned at the stake, she cried out to Azucena to avenge her.  Seeking this revenge, Azucena took the son of the Count of Luna at that time, planning on throwing it in the same fire that her mother died in.  In her madness, though, Azucena threw her own baby into the fire instead and kept the Count's son to herself.  This would make Manrico the brother of the current Count of Luna, but Azucena insists that Manrico is her son since she raised him and brought his health back when he was wounded.

title: Il balen del suo sorriso
subtitle: from Act II - The Gypsy, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Il Conte di Luna,  a young nobleman
setting: The convent near Castellor, 1409.
range: A3 to G4. Tessitura F3 to F4
synopsis: Leonora has decided to enter a convent after hearing that her love Manrico has died in battle.  The Count of Luna also loves her, though, and decides that if he steals her away from the convent, then she will love him.  In this aria, he confesses his love of Leonora to the world.

title: Per me ora fatale
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Il balen del suo sorriso from Act II - The Gypsy, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Il Conte di Luna,  a young nobleman
setting: The convent near Castellor, 1409.
range: C#/Db3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura F3 to F#/Gb4
synopsis: About to send his men to kidnap his love Leonora from the convent she is planning on entering, the Count of Luna sings of how his life is meaningless if he cannot have her.

title: Ah, s ben mio
subtitle: from Act III - The Gypsy's Son, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Manrico,  an officer in Prince Urgel's army and the supposed son of the gypsy woman Azucena
setting: A room adjoining the chapel at Castellor, 1409.
range: F3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Although the castle of Castellor is under siege, Manrico and Leonora are about to be married.  Manrico tells his love that, even if the fortress is destroyed and he is killed, he will die speaking her name.

title: Di quella pira
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Ah, s ben mio from Act III - The Gypsy's Son, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Manrico,  an officer in Prince Urgel's army and the supposed son of the gypsy woman Azucena

synopsis: Manrico has discovered that his mother Azucena has been captured by the Count of Luna and is about to be burned at the stake.  Furious, Manrico calls together his soldiers and sings valiantly of how they will save Azucena from death.

subtitle: from Act IV - The Torture, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi

range: C4 to D6. Tessitura F4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: Manrico has been captured in an attempt to save his mother from being executed and is now being held in prison by the Count of Luna.  Leonora has come to the prison in disguise in order to see him.  She hopes that he will be sustained by her love for him.

title: Tu vedrai che amore in terra
subtitle: - Cabaletta for D'amor sull'are rose from Act IV - The Torture, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Il Trovatore by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Leonora,  a lady-in-waiting for the Princess of Aragon
setting: A hall in the palace of Aliferia, Aragon, 1409.
range: C4 to C6. Tessitura E4 to A6
synopsis: Manrico has been captured in an attempt to save his mother from being executed and is now being held in prison by the Count of Luna.  Leonora has come to the prison in disguise in order to see him.  After hearing a choir of monks chant a prayer for the prisoners, Leonora sings of her great concern for her love.

title: Oh dans l'ombre, dans la mystre
subtitle: - Cavatina from Act I of the French opera, Jrusalem by Giuseppe Verdi

range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Roger is very attracted to his brother's daughter, Hlne who is betrothed to Gaston, the Vicomte of Barne.  He discusses with himself how he can get her for his own and, furthermore, how he can reconcile the incestuous love he feels.

subtitle: from Act I of the German opera, Tristan und Isolde by Richard Wagner

range: C4 to B6. Tessitura F4 to F5
synopsis: In a long narrative, Isolde tells the background of the opera.  She was affianced to Morald who was killed by Tristan.  Isolde decided to kill Tristan but then met him and fell in love with him and figured she would let him live.  Later, though, he came back for her to take her to Cornwall to mark King Marke.  This angered her even more than before and now she plans to kill him again.

title: Liebestod (Mild und leise)
subtitle: from Act III of the German opera, Tristan und Isolde by Richard Wagner

range: D#/Eb4 to G#/Ab5. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to F#/Gb5

title: Dnkt dich das?
subtitle: from Act III of the German opera, Tristan und Isolde by Richard Wagner
role: Tristan,  a Cornish knight and nephew to King Marke
setting: Tristan's castle at Karoel, Brittany, legendary times
range: D3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura G3 to F4

title: Mein Kurwenal, du trauter Freund
subtitle: from Act III of the German opera, Tristan und Isolde by Richard Wagner

setting: Tristan's castle at Karoel, Brittany, legendary times
range: D3 to A5. Tessitura A4 to G4
synopsis: After Kurnewal tells him that Isolde will soon be coming by ship, the somewhat delirious Tristan tells Kurnewal that he is a good man and then proceeds to wonder where the ship is.  After a short break, his memories go back to childhood.  After his thoughts return to the present time, he falls unconscious again.

title: Wie sie selig
subtitle: from Act III of the German opera, Tristan und Isolde by Richard Wagner
role: Tristan,  a Cornish knight and nephew to King Marke
setting: Tristan's castle at Karoel, Brittany, legendary times
range: D3 to F4. Tessitura A4 to E4
synopsis: As his delirium calms, Tristan thinks calmly about Isolde and her sweet visage.

subtitle: from Scene 3 of the English opera, Trouble in Tahiti by Leonard Bernstein

synopsis: Dinah tells her psychiatrist about a dream she had.  In the dream, she was in a dead garden.  But a voice tells her that there is another garden filled with love, harmony, and grace.  She goes to find the voice.  Every step she took was filled with terror and horrible things but with every step, the voice got closer.  Finally, she found him and when she touched his hand, he vanished and she woke up.

title: There's a law
subtitle: from Scene 5 of the English opera, Trouble in Tahiti by Leonard Bernstein
role: Sam,  a man in his early thirties
setting: A gymnasium in a suburb in the 1950's
range: C#/Db3 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Sam sings of his male prowess, saying that there are many kinds of men in the world, but only one type of man is a winner, implying that he is that man.

subtitle: from Scene 6 of the English opera, Trouble in Tahiti by Leonard Bernstein
role: Dinah,  a suburban wife in her early thirties

range: B4 to F5. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to D5
synopsis: Dinah has gone to see a terrible movie called "Trouble in Tahiti" which is a trite movie about Tahitian natives and a volcano that erupts, etc.  She describes the plot and the other aspects of the movie.

subtitle: - (Completed after Puccini's death) from Act I of the Italian opera, Turandot by Giacomo Puccini
setting: The streets of Peking
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Liù, Calaf and Timur are in the midst of a processional to the execution of the Prince of Persia who attempted to win the Princess Turandot by answering three riddles.  If he had given the correct answers, he would have married the Princess, but the price for incorrectly answering them was death.  During the processional, Calaf catches a glimpse of Turandot, falls in love with her immediately, and decides to attempt to answer the three riddles.  Liù sings this aria to beg him not to risk his life for the Princess.

title: In questa reggia
subtitle: - (Completed after Puccini's death) from Act II, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Turandot by Giacomo Puccini
setting: The square in front of the palace
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Turandot warns Calaf of the danger of the deadly game of riddles he proposes to take part in to win Turandot's name.  She explains to him that the game is to avenge her ancestress, who was killed when a warlord conquered her country.  Now, Turandot's self-devised game has settled the score.

title: Tu che di gel sei cinta
subtitle: - (Completed after Puccini's death) from Act III of the Italian opera, Turandot by Giacomo Puccini
setting: The gardens before the walls of Peking
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After being captured and tortured because she knows Calaf's name, Liù is asked by Turandot why she resists the torture so well.  She replies that her love for the "Unknown Prince" keeps her from telling his name.  She goes on to sing that Turandot's icy heart will one day be melted by Calaf and that Turandot will love him as Liù does now.

title: Non piangere, Li
subtitle: - (Completed after Puccini's death) from Act I of the Italian opera, Turandot by Giacomo Puccini
setting: The streets of Peking
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After Liù begs him tearfully not to risk his life by playing a deadly game to win the Princess Turandot, Calaf responds to her gently, asking her not to weep.

title: Nessun dorma
subtitle: - (Completed after Puccini's death) from Act III of the Italian opera, Turandot by Giacomo Puccini
setting: The gardens before the walls of Peking
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: A herald has just announced that no one will sleep in the Peking until the Calaf's name is known to the Princess under pain of death.  Calaf, who knows that he has agreed to be killed if Turandot learns his name before the morning, is not worried.  He is sure that he will be the only one to reveal his name to the Princess and this only after morning has come and the Princess has consented to be his wife.

title: Ma dall'arido stelo divulsa
subtitle: from Act II of the Italian opera, Un Ballo in Maschera by Giuseppe Verdi

subtitle: from Act III scene 1 of the Italian opera, Un Ballo in Maschera by Giuseppe Verdi

range: A4 to B6. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Renato threatens Amelia with death so that she will atone for the sins she has committed with Riccardo.  She pleads with Renato to see her son one last time before he kills her.

title: Saper vorreste
subtitle: - Canzone from Act III, scene 3 of the Italian opera, Un Ballo in Maschera by Giuseppe Verdi

range: D4 to B6. Tessitura G4 to G5

title: Re dell'abisso, affrettati
subtitle: from Act I, scene 2 of the Italian opera, Un Ballo in Maschera by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: Ulrica's hut near Boston, late 17th century
range: G3 to C#/Db6. Tessitura C4 to F5
synopsis: Ulrica calls upon the King of the Abyss to enter her dwelling so she can do his bidding.

title: La rivedr nell'estasi
subtitle: - Cavatina from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Un Ballo in Maschera by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A hall in the Governor's house, Boston, late 17th century.
range: F3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura F#/Gb3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Riccardo is given a list of people who have been invited to the ball the next day and on that list is Amelia's name.  He sings of his love for her.

title: Di' tu se fedele
subtitle: - Canzone from Act I, scene 2 of the Italian opera, Un Ballo in Maschera by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: Ulrica's hut near Boston, late 17th century
range: C3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to F#/Gb4
synopsis: Awaiting his fortune to be told, Riccardo arrogantly proclaims that nothing can keep him from the sea or the woman he loves.

title: Ma se m' forza perderti
subtitle: from Act III, scene 2 of the Italian opera, Un Ballo in Maschera by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A hall in the Governor's house, Boston, late 17th century.
range: F#/Gb3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura G3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Alone, Riccardo contemplates his misguided love for Amelia.  He decides to send Amelia and Renato to their homeland in an effort to rid his heart of the ill-gotten love.

title: Se piet di me non senti
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 3 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: Palace of the Goddess of Virtue, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: E4 to A6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Caesar has run outside to fight against Tolomeo's soldiers who are trying to take his life.  Inside, Cleopatra finds that she now loves Caesar instead of just pretending to love him so that she would be favored above Tolomeo.  She still hopes that Caesar will be able to gain revenge on Tolomeo.

title: L'aure che spira
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 4 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
role: Sesto,  son of Cornelia and Pompey
setting: garden of the King's harem, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: B3 to G4. Tessitura E3 to G4
synopsis: Sesto runs into the harem and attempts to stab Tolomeo but is prevented by Achilla.  He then attempts to kill himself but is prevented by his mother Cornelia who gives him strength.  He then declares his refound determination to have revenge upon Tolomeo.

title: Pianger la sorte mia
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: woods near Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: E4 to A6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Her brother Tolomeo has ordered Cleopatra to prison for scheming with the now-apparently-drowned Caesar.  Saddened by the turn of events, Cleopatra contemplates what fate has given her and how, when she is dead, she could come back and haunt her brother.

title: Dall'ondoAure, deh, per piet spirate
subtitle: - Recit. and Aria from Act III, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: the harbour, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: C3 to D4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: In an attempt against his life, Caesar was thought to have drowned in the harbour.  In actuality, he survived and tells of his escape.  He then prays for relief to his loneliness.

title: La giustizia ha gi sull'arco
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
role: Sesto,  son of Cornelia and Pompey
setting: the harbour, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: D3 to G4. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: Sesto and Caesar have now joined forces against their mutual enemy Tolomeo.  They hatch a plan in which Sesto will command some of the troops entering Tolomeo's palace through an underground route.  Sesto rejoices, believing that at last the murder of his father Pompey will be revenged.

title: Da tempeste il legno infranto
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 3 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: Cleopatra's room, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: D#/Eb4 to A6. Tessitura G#/Ab4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: Just before Cleopatra leaves to go to prison, Caesar breaks into her apartments and liberates her from the clutches of Cleopatra's wicked brother, Tolomeo.  In jubilation, she anticipates the victory that is sure to follow.

title: Sombre fret
subtitle: - No. 9, Recitative and Romance from Act II of the French opera, Guillaume Tell by Gioacchino Rossini
libretto: tienne de Jouy ,  Florent Bis, and Armand Marast
role: Mathilde,  an Austrian Princess in the house of Hapsburg
setting: the forested heights of Rtli over Waldstetten lake nera the town of Brunnen, Switzerland, thirteenth century
range: C4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to F5

She trembles in anticipation of seeing the man to whom she has given her heart.  She decides that she prefers the lonely forest to the pleasures of the palace because it is the only place that she can reveal her secret longings and desires.

title: Pour notre amourSur la rive trangre
subtitle: - part of No. 13, Duet from Act III, Scene 1 of the French opera, Guillaume Tell by Gioacchino Rossini
libretto: tienne de Jouy ,  Florent Bis, and Armand Marast
role: Mathilde,  an Austrian Princess in the house of Hapsburg
setting: the interior of a ruined chapel on the grounds of the Governor's palace at Altdorf, Switzerland, thirteenth century
range: B4 to B6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Arnold has informed Mathilde that he must leave her in order to avenge her father's death and support the cause of the Swiss resistance to the Austrian rule.  Mathilde is devastated and believes that all her happy moments with Arnold are now over.  Although her sense of reason understands his reasons, her heart wishes that Arnold could forget his dangerous pursuit of revenge and instead stay with her.  Finally though, she gives him her entire support and tells him that, although she cannot be there with him in person, she will be with him in his heart.

title: Sois immobile

He dreamed that he was lying underneath an oak that had a image of the Virgin Mary painted on it.  Suddenly, the painting spoke and told him to take a sword and a helmet and place them before it.  He ends by praying again that France be saved.

title: Pondo  letal martirio
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Sotto una quercia parvemi from Prologue, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Giovanna d'Arco by Giuseppe Verdi
