The king dismisses their worries, singing that since he has dreamed this tree has the Madonna painted upon it, the Devil will not be able to intrude.  He isn't worried about the Devil, but he is worried about his crown for he does not want to be king any longer.

title: Sempre all'alba ed alla sera
subtitle: - Cavatina from Prologue, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Giovanna d'Arco by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A forest, France, 1429
range: D#/Eb4 to D6. Tessitura E4 to A6
synopsis: Giovanna is upset because she cannot help defend her France in its darkest hour because she is a woman.  She prays to the Madonna that she will be given weapons with which she can fight against the English intruders.

title: Franco son io
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Giovanna d'Arco by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A rocky area close to the city of Rheims, France, 1429
range: B3 to F4. Tessitura G3 to F4
synopsis: The English are in retreat and are about to pull out of France altogether when Giacomo approaches them.  He offers to hand over his daughter to them for she was the one who rallied the French to victory.  He does love his country but he cannot help but fight against the French king whom he believes has brought dishonor upon them all.

title: So che per via dei triboli
subtitle: - Cabaletta fot Franco son io from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Giovanna d'Arco by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A rocky area close to the city of Rheims, France, 1429
range: C3 to F4. Tessitura F3 to F4
synopsis: The English are in retreat and are about to pull out of France altogether when Giacomo approaches them.  He offers to hand over his daughter to them for she was the one who rallied the French to victory.  After railing against the disgrace of the French king that caused Giacomo to betray his country, he continues on into this cabaletta attempting to reconcile his love for his daughter that he is betraying.

title: O fatidica foresta
subtitle: - Romanza from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Giovanna d'Arco by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A garden in the Court of Rheims, France, 1429
range: D4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura F4 to F5
synopsis: Giovanna has commanded the French troops to victory over the English and has accomplished what she set out to do.  She is still at the court but she wishes to return to her old life as a shepherdess.  She sings longingly of her small cottage, the forest that surrounded it, and her father whom she misses dearly.

title: Speme al vecchio ora una figlia
subtitle: - Romanza from Act II of the Italian opera, Giovanna d'Arco by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: The main square in front of the Cathedral of St. Denis in Rheims, France, 1429
range: C3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura F#/Gb3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Giacomo has now come to terms with his betrayal of his daughter to the English.  He is sure now that it will be the best for France if he rids the country of this woman whom he believes has gone over to the Devil.  He sings of her as she used to be a obedient, faithful daughter who would have taken care of him for the rest of his years.  He regrets that now he must turn her in, but resolves that he will do his part by making sure she is not burned at the stake.

title: Comparire il ciel m'ha stretto
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Speme al vecchio ora una figlia from Act II of the Italian opera, Giovanna d'Arco by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: The main square in front of the Cathedral of St. Denis in Rheims, France, 1429
range: C3 to F4. Tessitura E3 to E4
synopsis: Carlo has declared to the crowd in front of the cathedral of St. Denis that another cathedral should be raised up in honor of Giovanna who has saved all of France.  Suddenly, Giacomo bursts out of the crowd yelling "Blasphemy!"  He goes on to denounce her, singing that he saw her in the forest when she gave herself over to Satan and King Carlo and God has declared that she should be punished for her evil actions.  As he finishes up his accusations, he asks the crowd furiously if they will raise a cathedral to her now.

title: Quale al pi fido amico
subtitle: - Romanza from Act III of the Italian opera, Giovanna d'Arco by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Carlo VII,  the King of France
setting: The inside of a English Army fort
range: E3 to G4. Tessitura A4 to F4
synopsis: Giacomo has realized that his daughter Giovanna's actions to save France were not prompted by the Devil and releases her from captivity by the English.  She goes off to fight against the English and saves them and helps them conquer the English.  In doing so, though, she is killed on the field of battle.  After conquering the English, Carlo and Giacomo are informed of this unfortunate news.  While Giacomo weeps, Carlo expresses his grief at her death.

title: Priva son d'ogni conforto
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: the bridge over the Nile entering Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: B4 to D5. Tessitura D4 to C5
synopsis: Cornelia's husband, Pompey, has been killed by the Egyptians to show their loyalty to Caesar.  After unsuccessfully attempting suicide, she sings of her unhappiness and her loneliness.

title: Svegliatevi nel core
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
role: Sesto,  son of Cornelia and Pompey
setting: the bridge over the Nile entering Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: C3 to G4. Tessitura F3 to F4
synopsis: Sesto's father, Pompey, has been killed by the Egyptians to show their loyalty to Caesar.  Upset, he vows that he will have revenge upon those that committed the crime.

title: Non disperar
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: Cleopatra's room, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: E4 to A6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Cleopatra has heard that her brother Tolomeo has killed Caesar's rival, Pompey, in order to influence Caesar.  Cleopatra also wants to influence Caesar, but she decides to use her beauty to seduce him instead.

title: Non  si vago e bello
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: Cleopatra's room, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: B3 to B4. Tessitura B3 to B4
synopsis: Caesar sees Cleopatra for the first time and is entranced by her beauty.

title: Cara speme, questo core
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
role: Sesto,  son of Cornelia and Pompey
setting: Cleopatra's room, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: D3 to G4. Tessitura E3 to E4
synopsis: Cleopatra is in disguise and using the name Lidia.  She overhears Cornelia and Sesto planning to avenge Pompey's murder by Cleopatra's brother Tolomeo.  Cleopatra offers her help and Sesto rejoices, believing that they will soon have their revenge.

title: Tu la mia stella sei
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: Cleopatra's room, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: E4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: After joining with Cornelia and Sesto in a plot to kill her brother Tolomeo, Cleopatra rejoices in the idea of the fall of Tolomeo and, presumably, her rise to greater power.

title: Va tacito e nascosto
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 3 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: palace of Tolomeo, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: C3 to D4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Tolomeo and Caesar meet in a banquet.  When Tolomeo subtly threatens him, Caesar responds, saying that he will be on guard against any violence Tolomeo has planned.

title: V'adoro pupille
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: Palace of the Goddess of Virtue, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: F4 to G5. Tessitura G4 to F5
synopsis: Cleopatra sings a beautiful love song designed to seduce Caesar from afar.

title: L'angue offeso mai riposa
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
role: Sesto,  son of Cornelia and Pompey
setting: garden of the King's harem, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: C3 to G4. Tessitura F3 to F4
synopsis: Sesto likens the revenge he plans on taking against Tolomeo to a striking serpent.

title: Al lampo dell'armi
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 3 of the Italian opera, Giulio Cesare (Julius Caesar) by George Frideric Handel
setting: Palace of the Goddess of Virtue, Alexandria, Egypt, 48 B.C.
range: C3 to D4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Cleopatra knows of an attempt on Caesar's life that is about to be made by Tolomeo's soldiers.  However, when she tries to warn him to flee, he at first repudiates the idea vigorously.  He then runs out to take part in the fighting.

title: Dans l'ombre et la silence (Nell'ombra e nel silenzio)
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Et toi, Palerme from Act II of the French|Italian opera, Les Vpres Siciliennes (I Vespri Siciliani) by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Jean Procida (Giovanni da Procida),  a Sicilian doctor
setting: A valley near Palermo, 1282
range: A#/Bb3 to F4. Tessitura C3 to C#/Db4
synopsis: Procida is returning to Sicily after an absence to attempt to gather help to free Sicily from the oppression of the French.  He sings of the vengeance he will help his country obtain.

title: Au sein de la puissance (In braccio alle dovizie)
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 1 of the French|Italian opera, Les Vpres Siciliennes (I Vespri Siciliani) by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Guy de Montfort (Guido di Monforte),  the Governor of Sicily under the rule of Charles d'Anjou
setting: a room in Montfort's palace, Palermo, 1282
range: C#/Db3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura C#/Db3 to E4
synopsis: Montfort finds out that the son he had with a Sicilian woman eighteen years ago is one of the Sicilian rebels.  He goes on to sing that, although he feels distanced from the rest of society because of his power, his life is kept buoyant with the news of his son being alive.

title: O jour de peine (Giorno di pianto)
subtitle: - Romance from Act IV of the French|Italian opera, Les Vpres Siciliennes (I Vespri Siciliani) by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: the courtyard of a castle, Palermo, 1282
range: E3 to B5. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to A5
synopsis: Henri worries that Hlne and Procida will not accept his reasons for betraying their plot to kill Governor Montfort.  Although he wants to free Sicily from the oppression of the French, he has recently found out that Montfort was his father and thus does not want him to be killed.

title: Merci, jeunes amies (Merc, dilette amiche)
subtitle: - Sicilienne from Act V of the French|Italian opera, Les Vpres Siciliennes (I Vespri Siciliani) by Giuseppe Verdi
role: La Duchesse Hlne (La Duchessa Elena),  Duke Frederick of Austria's sister
setting: the gardens of the palace of Montfort, Palermo, 1282
range: A4 to C#/Db6. Tessitura E4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: After being married to Henri, Hlne sings of her great joy in a dance-like fashion that is more akin to a Spanish bolero than a siciliana.

title: Le brise souffle au loin (La brezza aleggia intorno)
subtitle: - Mlodie from Act V of the French|Italian opera, Les Vpres Siciliennes (I Vespri Siciliani) by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: the gardens of the palace of Montfort, Palermo, 1282
range: E3 to D5. Tessitura A4 to G4
synopsis: After being married to Hlne, Henri sings of his love for her sweetly and charmingly.

title: Einsam in trben Tagen (Elsa's Dream)
subtitle: from Act I of the German opera, Lohengrin by Richard Wagner
role: Elsa of Brabant,  a young woman
setting: a plain on the banks of the Schelbt, Antwerp, first half of the 10th century
range: D#/Eb4 to G#/Ab5. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to D#/Eb5
synopsis: Elsa relates a dream she had where a Knight in white was sent to her by God to defend her.

title: O fnd' ich Jubelweisen
subtitle: from Act I of the German opera, Lohengrin by Richard Wagner
role: Elsa of Brabant,  a young woman
setting: a plain on the banks of the Schelbt, Antwerp, first half of the 10th century
range: F4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura A#/Bb5 to G5
synopsis: Elsa sings her praise to God for all that he has done for her, including sending a holy Knight to protect her.

title: Erhebe dich, Genossin meiner Schmach
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the German opera, Lohengrin by Richard Wagner
role: Frederick of Telramund,  the Count of Brabant
setting: the fortress of Antwerp outside the Knight's palace, first half of the 10th century
range: C3 to G4. Tessitura F#/Gb3 to E4
synopsis: Frederick and his wife Ortrud have been banished by the King for their pagan ways.  Frederick believes that their downfall was Ortrud's fault and tells her.

title: Euch Lften, die mein Klagen
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the German opera, Lohengrin by Richard Wagner
role: Elsa of Brabant,  a young woman
setting: the balcony of Elsa's room in the fortress of Antwerp outside the Knight's palace, first half of the 10th century
range: E4 to F5. Tessitura A5 to F5
synopsis: Excited by the thought of her rapidly approaching marriage, Elsa thanks the breezes that have sent her such joy.

title: Athmest du nicht mit mir die sssen Dfte
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 1 of the German opera, Lohengrin by Richard Wagner
setting: Elsa's bridal chamber, Antwerp, first half of the 10th century
range: G3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: Because Lohengrin is not allowed to tell her his name, Elsa becomes suspicious about his true feelings for her.  He attempts to reassure her by comparing her to all the sweetest fragrances floating through the air.

title: In fernem Land
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 2 of the German opera, Lohengrin by Richard Wagner
setting: a plain on the banks of the Schelbt, Antwerp, first half of the 10th century
range: E3 to A5. Tessitura G3 to F#/Gb4
synopsis: To this point, the Knight has not been allowed to tell his name or his origin.  However, he now must leave because he has killed Frederick, the Count of Brabant, and now tells his past.  He is a Knight of the Grail from the island of Montsalvat and his father is Parsifal, the leader of all the Knights of Grail who strive to do good in the world as long as no one knows their secret.  He finally reveals that his true name is Lohengrin.

title: Mein lieber Schwan
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 2 of the German opera, Lohengrin by Richard Wagner
setting: a plain on the banks of the Schelbt, Antwerp, first half of the 10th century
range: F#/Gb3 to A5. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: As a beautiful swan floats towards them, Lohengrin says goodbye to Elsa.  He tells her that her brother Gottfried who disappeared a while ago would have reappeared in a year if Lohengrin did not have to leave.  However, he is now forced to leave and gives his sword, his ring, and his horn to Elsa, saying that Gottfried should be given them when he returns.

title: Thousands of Miles
subtitle: - No. 2 from Act I, Scene 1 of the English opera, Lost in the Stars by Kurt Weill
role: Reverend Stephen Kumalo,  a South African preacher in the village of Ndotsheni
setting: Stephen's house in Ndotsheni, a small village in South Africa, first half of the 20th century
range: A3 to C4. Tessitura C3 to C4
synopsis: Stephen's son, Absalom, is far away in Johannesburg and his mother Grace wonders if he has changed.  Stephen explains to his wife that if people love each other, the distance between them doesn't matter.

title: The Little Gray House
subtitle: - No. 7 from Act I, Scene 5 of the English opera, Lost in the Stars by Kurt Weill
role: Reverend Stephen Kumalo,  a South African preacher in the village of Ndotsheni
setting: Stephen's Shantytown Lodging, Johannesburg, South Africa, first half of the 20th century
range: G#/Ab2 to C#/Db4. Tessitura D3 to G#/Ab3
synopsis: Stephen tells his sister and her son about the little house and the village that he lives in and promises to take her son back with him when he leaves Johannesburg.

title: Who'll Buy?
subtitle: - No. 8 from Act I, Scene 6 of the English opera, Lost in the Stars by Kurt Weill
setting: A dive in Shantytown, Johannesburg, South Africa, first half of the 20th century
range: A#/Bb4 to D5. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to C5
synopsis: Linda sings a suggestive song asking who will buy her "fresh produce".  She claims that they are the best that anyone has ever laid their lips on.

title: Trouble Man
subtitle: - No. 10 from Act I, Scene 7 of the English opera, Lost in the Stars by Kurt Weill
setting: Irina's hut in Shantytown, Johannesburg, South Africa, first half of the 20th century
range: C4 to F5. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to D#/Eb5
synopsis: Even though Absalom continues to get himself into trouble, Irina still proclaims her undying love for him.

title: Lost in the Stars
subtitle: - No. 15 from Act I, Scene 11 of the English opera, Lost in the Stars by Kurt Weill
role: Reverend Stephen Kumalo,  a South African preacher in the village of Ndotsheni
setting: Prison, Johannesburg, South Africa, first half of the 20th century
range: G#/Ab2 to F4. Tessitura B3 to C4
synopsis: Stephen's son has been arrested for killing a white man.  Stephen visits him in prison and, although he wants to do what he can for the boy, he wonders if God has gone away and left mankind lost in the stars.

title: O Tixo, Tixo, Help Me
subtitle: - No. 18 from Act 2, Scene 2 of the English opera, Lost in the Stars by Kurt Weill
role: Reverend Stephen Kumalo,  a South African preacher in the village of Ndotsheni
setting: John Kumalo's tobacco shop, Johannesburg, South Africa, first half of the 20th century
range: C3 to F4. Tessitura D3 to E4
synopsis: Stephen prays to God to let his son go free, saying that his son did not mean to kill anyone and now has no recourse except for intervention from above.

title: Stay Well
subtitle: - No. 19 from Act 2, Scene 4 of the English opera, Lost in the Stars by Kurt Weill
setting: Irina's hut in Shantytown, Johannesburg, South Africa, first half of the 20th century
range: C4 to F5. Tessitura F4 to D#/Eb5
synopsis: Irina has found out that her love Absalom has killed a man and may be sentenced to death.  She says that she will continue to love him and hopes that she will see him at her door again..

title: Big Mole
subtitle: - No. 23 from Act 2, Scene 7 of the English opera, Lost in the Stars by Kurt Weill
setting: Ndotsheni, a small village in South Africa, first half of the 20th century
range: A#/Bb4 to C5. Tessitura D4 to C5
synopsis: Alex is digging a hole in the ground and sings a story about the best digger in the world, Big Mole.

title: Smanie implacabili
subtitle: - No. 11 from Act I, Scene III of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Dorabella,  sister of Fiordiligi and fiancee of Ferrando
setting: the living room of Dorabella and Fiordiligi's house
range: D4 to G5. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: After her fiance has gone off to war, Dorabella grieves his leaving and overreacts somewhat to the point where she is hysterical.  In this mock-heroic aria, she is singing that her grief is too much to bear and thus, she should die.

title: amore un ladroncello
subtitle: - No. 28 from Act II, Scene III of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Dorabella,  sister of Fiordiligi and fiancee of Ferrando
setting: a room in Dorabella and Fiordiligi's house
range: E4 to G5. Tessitura F4 to F5
synopsis: Fiordiligi wants to remain faithful to her fiancee, but, in this aria, Dorabella tries to convince her to agree to marry the Albanian.  She compares love to a thief, saying that if they oppose love, they will be in torment, but if they follow their hearts, they will have a much easier time.

title: Un aura amorosa
subtitle: - No. 17 from Act I, Scene III of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Ferrando,  a soldier who is in love with Dorabella
setting: the living room of Dorabella and Fiordiligi
range: D3 to A5. Tessitura A4 to A5
synopsis: Guglielmo complains of his hunger but, in this aria, Ferrando tells him he should hold his appetite, for even the possibility of love from their beloveds will sate one's hunger at once.

title: Ah lo veggio
subtitle: - No. 24 from Act II, Scene II of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Ferrando,  a soldier who is in love with Dorabella
setting: the garden of Dorabella and Fiordiligi
range: F3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura G3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Ferrando disguised as an Albanian is alone with Fiordiligi.  He attempts to woo her and sings this aria when he thinks she is beginning to weaken, saying that her gentle nature cannot resist his charms.

title: Tradito, schernito
subtitle: - No. 27, Cavatina from Act II, Scene II of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Ferrando,  a soldier who is in love with Dorabella
setting: the garden of Dorabella and Fiordiligi
range: F3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura G3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Tormented that Dorabella would betray him for another man, Ferrando sings of his anger but declares that he still loves Dorabella.

title: Non siate ritrosi
subtitle: - No. 15 from Act I, Scene III of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Guglielmo,  a soldier in love with Fiordiligi
setting: the living room of Dorabella and Fiordiligi
range: D3 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: After Fiordiligi basically asks the soldiers disguised as Albanians to leave, Guglielmo sings this aria describing their many virtues, including their big muscles and their large moustaches.

title: Rivolgete a lui lo sguardo
subtitle: - No. 15a from Act I, Scene III of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Guglielmo,  a soldier in love with Fiordiligi
setting: the living room of Dorabella and Fiordiligi
range: G2 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura D3 to E4
synopsis: This aria was actually replaced in the opera by

title: Donne mie, le fate a tanti
subtitle: - No.26 from Act II, Scene II of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Guglielmo,  a soldier in love with Fiordiligi
setting: the garden of Fiordiligi and Dorabella
range: B3 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Guglielmo, having succeeded in wooing his friend's fiance, comments on the unfaithfulness of women.  He declares women who treat all men in such a bad way deserve to have their lovers complain about them.

title: Vorrei dir, e cor non ho
subtitle: - No. 5 from Act I, Scene II of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: A garden overlooking the Bay of Naples
range: D#/Eb3 to D#/Eb4. Tessitura F3 to C#/Db4
synopsis: Don Alfonso arrives to tell Fiordiligi and Dorabella terrible news.  He tells them that their fiances, Guglielmo and Ferrando, have been called away on active duty.  In reality, though, they have not.  They are just playing a trick on their fiancees.

title: Tutti accusan le donne
subtitle: - No. 30 from Act II, Scene III of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: A room in Dorabella and Fiordiligi's house
range: C3 to E4. Tessitura E3 to D4
synopsis: After Fiordiligi gives into Ferrando's courtship, Alfonso soothes both of the soldiers, singing that women should not be held accountable for their actions for they are naturally flirtatious.  Rather, it is the soldiers' own fault because they were not active enough in their original courtship of their fiancees.

title: O wie gerne blieb ich bei dir
subtitle: from the one-act German opera, Daphne by Richard Strauss
role: Daphne,  daughter of Gaea and Peneios
setting: near the hut of Penios, ancient Greece
range: D4 to C6. Tessitura G4 to A6
synopsis: The love of Daphne, Leukippos, has been killed by the god Apollo.  In her sorrow, Daphne accepts that it was her fault that he died and vows to stay by his grave until the gods take her life away.

title: Jeden heiligen Morgen
subtitle: from the one-act German opera, Daphne by Richard Strauss
setting: near the hut of Penios, ancient Greece
range: C#/Db3 to B5. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Leukippos has accused Apollo of lying about his godhood and, to prove that he truly is a god, Apollo kills him.  However, Daphne then swears to remain at the grave of her beloved Leukippos until she joins him in death.  Realizing that he might have made a mistake, Apollo asks Dionysius, the god of wine, for forgiveness.  To make up for his mistake, Apollo begs that Leukippos be raised to Olympus, home of the gods, in order to forevermore play the flute for Dionysius.  He then begs the father of the gods, Zeus, to have similar mercy upon Daphne and change her into aone of her beloved laurel trees.

title: O mein Leukippos
subtitle: from the one-act German opera, Daphne by Richard Strauss
role: Daphne,  daughter of Gaea and Peneios
setting: near the hut of Penios, ancient Greece
range: D#/Eb3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura A4 to G4
synopsis: Revealing his true identity, Apollo explains how every morning he rides his golden chariot into the sky and shoots a glowing arrow through the air arcing over the earth.

title: Gtter, Brder im hohen Olympos
subtitle: from the one-act German opera, Daphne by Richard Strauss
setting: near the hut of Penios, ancient Greece
range: C#/Db4 to B6. Tessitura G4 to A6
synopsis: Although the merry feast day celebrating Dionysus, god of wine and revelry, approaches, Daphne feels no anticipation of any human joy.  Instead, she tells of her love of nature and how she feels more at one with the trees and flowers than with humankind.

title: Du kennest jenen stillen Ort (O, eile, Freund)
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 1 of the German opera, Das Liebesverbot by Richard Wagner
libretto: Richard Wagner ,  adapted from Shakespeare's Measure for Measure
setting: in front of Danieli's tavern in a suburb of Palermo, Sicily, 16th century
range: E3 to B5. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: Claudio has been arrested for breaking the new law against fornication and other immoral activities.  If convicted, he will be sentenced to death.  As he is being dragged away, he calls out to his friend Luzio to hurry to the convent where his sister Isabella is cloistered.  He believes that only Isabella will be able to help him.

title: Ach, knnt'ich nur ein wenig richten
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 3 of the German opera, Das Liebesverbot by Richard Wagner
libretto: Richard Wagner ,  adapted from Shakespeare's Measure for Measure
setting: a courtroom in Palermo, Sicily, 16th century
range: G2 to D4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Brighella is sitting in the courtroom waiting for the judge to arrive.  However, the judge is late and Brighella wishes that he had the chance to judge cases.

title: Kennst du das LeidO war dein Herz
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 3 of the German opera, Das Liebesverbot by Richard Wagner
libretto: Richard Wagner ,  adapted from Shakespeare's Measure for Measure
role: Isabella,  a novice in the Convent of St. Elizabeth's
setting: a courtroom in Palermo, Sicily, 16th century
range: A#/Bb4 to B6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Isabella has come to the courtroom to plead for the life of her brother, Claudio, who has been sentenced to death for the crime of illegal fornication.  She asks the Governor, Friedrich, to pardon Claudio, arguing that he cannot refuse the wishes of the orphan sister that she is. When Friedrich refuses her, she tries a different tack, accusing him of abusing God's gift of love. He sings that a happy marriage needs one more thing besides love, though, and that is gold.  He sings that gold makes a happy house and, without gold, love means nothing.  Who can be happy if you are hungry all the time?

title: Ha!  welch' ein Augenblick!
subtitle: - No. 7, Aria with Chorus from Act I, Scene 5 of the German opera, Fidelio by Ludwig van Beethoven
role: Pizarro,  the overseer of the prison
setting: The courtyard of a prison close to Seville
range: G#/Ab2 to E4. Tessitura C3 to D4
synopsis: Pizarro is holding Florestan illegally as a prisoner deep in his dungeons.  He has received a letter that the Minister (Fernando) will soon be arriving and will be inspecting the prison to make sure that every prisoner is being legally held.  Pizarro knows that he will be in deep trouble if Florestan is found so he decides that he will solve everything by killing Florestan immediately.

title: Abscheulicher! wo eilst du hin?...Komm, Hoffnung, lass den letzten Stern
subtitle: - No. 9, Recitative and Aria from Act I, Scene 6 of the German opera, Fidelio by Ludwig van Beethoven
setting: The courtyard of a prison close to Seville
range: B4 to B6. Tessitura E4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Leonora overhears Pizarro talking to Rocco about killing a prisoner whom she believes is her husband, Florestan.  She wonders how he can be so cruel, but soon decides that love will help her overcome his evil plans.

title: Gott! welch' Dunkel hier!
subtitle: - No. 11, Introduction and Aria from Act II, Scene 1 of the German opera, Fidelio by Ludwig van Beethoven
setting: The dungeon of a prison near Seville
range: D#/Eb3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to A5
synopsis: Imprisoned and close to death, Florestan sings that even though his life is now joyless, he can find solace because he has done his duty and he knows that what he did was right.  He then thinks that he sees a vision of his wife Leonora coming as an angel to lead him to heaven.

title: O mio babbino caro
subtitle: from the one-act Italian opera, Gianni Schicchi by Giacomo Puccini
role: Lauretta,  the daughter of Gianni Schicchi
setting: The bedroom of Buoso Donati, Florence, Italy, 1299
range: D#/Eb4 to G#/Ab5. Tessitura F4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: Buoso Donati has died and his relatives have found his will and discoverd that he has left all his money to the church.  Furious, they do not know what to do.  Rinuccio, who is in love with Lauretta but is forbidden to marry her unless he was left some of the inheritance, sends for Gianni Schicchi and Lauretta to see if they can help them.  When the relatives find this out, they are furious and argue with Gianni Schicchi.  Fed up, he starts to leave, but Lauretta stops him with this aria, singing that she loves Rinuccio and if doesn't help them, she will throw herself in the river and die.

title: Firenze  come un albero fiorito
subtitle: from the one-act Italian opera, Gianni Schicchi by Giacomo Puccini
setting: The bedroom of Buoso Donati, Florence, Italy, 1299

synopsis: After telling his family that he has called for Gianni Schicchi to help them regain their inheritance, he proceeds to sing them a noble song which extolls the virtues of Florence and that Gianni Schicchi embodies all of them.

synopsis: Ariadne's despair is great because she has been abandoned by her love Theseus.  The Harlequin tries to cheer her up, saying that she should give life another chance, since life's joys can really be surprising.

title: Gromchtige PrinzessinSo war es mit Pagliazzo
subtitle: - Recitative and Aria from Opera of the German opera, Ariadne auf Naxos by Richard Strauss
role: Zerbinetta,  a member of a commedia dell'arte group

Gaily and quite floridly she describes her romantic adventures, going through lists of names of men she enjoyed and how she let them seduce her.

range: Has not been entered yet.

Ariodante then sings of his unhappiness and despair.

range: E3 to A5. Tessitura F3 to F4
synopsis: Camille is in love with Baron Mirko Zeta's wife Valencienne.  He compares his love for her to a rosebud that blossoms overnight into full bloom.

title: Wahn! Wahn! Uberall Wahn!
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 1 of the German opera, Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg by Richard Wagner
setting: the workshop of Sachs, Nuremburg, Germany, mid-sixteenth century
range: A3 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Brooding over the riot of the previous night in which his apprentice David was involved, Sachs philosophizes over the madness that is rampant throughout the world.  He tries to figure out how the madness that causes such things as war and riots can instead be harnessed to produce good things.

title: O Sachs!  Mein Freund
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 1 of the German opera, Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg by Richard Wagner
setting: the workshop of Sachs, Nuremburg, Germany, mid-sixteenth century
range: C#/Db4 to B6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to G5
synopsis: Eva tells Sachs that she really thinks a lot of him but only in a platonic sense.  She thanks him for teaching her what love is, now that she has found it with Walter.

title: Walter's Prize Song (Morgenlich leuchtend im rosigen Schein)
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 2 of the German opera, Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg by Richard Wagner
role: Walter von Stolzing,  a young knight from Franconia
setting: a meadow outside of Nuremburg, Germany, mid-sixteenth century
range: D#/Eb3 to A5. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: Walter sings his Prize Song for the song contest.  It is a beautiful and magical piece which poetically describes his love for Eva.

title: Verachtet mir die Meister nicht
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 2 of the German opera, Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg by Richard Wagner
setting: a meadow outside of Nuremburg, Germany, mid-sixteenth century
range: C3 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: After Walter refuses the membership offered to him by the Mastersingers Guild, Sachs tells him that the Masters have actually helped preserve German Art which Sachs believes that should be kept pure without any foreign influences.

title: Schumacherei und Poeterei
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the German opera, Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg by Richard Wagner
setting: a makeshift arena, Nuremburg, Germany, mid-sixteenth century
range: C#/Db3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura F3 to G4
synopsis: David gives Walter, the new candidate for the Mastersingers Guild, a rundown of all the different confusing rules of the Guild that Walter will have to follow in order to gain admission to the Guild.

title: Pogner's Address (Nun hrt, und versteht mich recht!)
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the German opera, Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg by Richard Wagner
setting: a makeshift arena, Nuremburg, Germany, mid-sixteenth century
range: C3 to F4. Tessitura C3 to D4
synopsis: Pogner arrives and tells everyone why he decided to hold a song contest with his daughter as the prize.  Apparently, Nuremburg is perceived by others as a pretty boring place.  So, Pogner figures that a song contest would show everyone else how good a place it is.

title: Am stillen Herd in Winterszeit
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the German opera, Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg by Richard Wagner
role: Walter von Stolzing,  a young knight from Franconia
setting: a makeshift arena, Nuremburg, Germany, mid-sixteenth century
range: D3 to A5. Tessitura F#/Gb3 to F#/Gb4
synopsis: Walter is asked by the Masters what kind of training he had.  He tells them his educational background, which isn't very substantial.  The references he gives are dead and the rest of his learning is from life.

title: Ein jedes Meistergesanges Bar
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the German opera, Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg by Richard Wagner
setting: a makeshift arena, Nuremburg, Germany, mid-sixteenth century
range: C3 to E4. Tessitura E3 to D4
synopsis: Kothner recites the long and confusing rules of becoming a Mastersinger.  If Walter breaks seven of the rules while he sings his trial song, the Guild will not allow him to join.

title: So rief der Lenz in den Wald
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the German opera, Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg by Richard Wagner
role: Walter von Stolzing,  a young knight from Franconia
setting: a makeshift arena, Nuremburg, Germany, mid-sixteenth century
range: F3 to A5. Tessitura F3 to G4
synopsis: Walter sings his trial song to the Masters in an attempt to get into the Mastersinger Guild.  Passionate and unrestrained, it is a song in praise of spring.  It receives a bad reception from the rule-bound Masters except for the more liberal Sachs.

title: Questo amor, vergogna mia
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, Edgar by Giacomo Puccini
setting: the main square of a Flemish village at dawn in April, late 19th century
range: D3 to F4. Tessitura F3 to E4
synopsis: Frank looks at Tigrana from afar and sings of his love for her.  He has grown up with her and loves her very much, but she does not return the love and, in fact, is wrongful since they are almost like brother and sister.

title: Tu il cuor mi strazi
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, Edgar by Giacomo Puccini
role: Tigrana,  a woman in love with Edgar
setting: the main square of a Flemish village at dawn in April, late 19th century
range: C4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to D#/Eb5
synopsis: Tigrana comes out from an inn and sits on a table and begins a provocative song.  She accompanies herself on the dembal (a type of lute).  Her song speaks of her lack of belief in religion.

title: O soave vison
subtitle: from Act II of the Italian opera, Edgar by Giacomo Puccini
role: Edgar,  a young man in love with Fidelia
setting: a terrace next to a garden, a village in Flanders, late 19th century
range: D#/Eb3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Edgar reveals that he is tired with his pleasure-filled life with Tigrana and that he wishes he could return to the simple life in his old village that he threw away before.  He especially misses Fidelia.

title: Addio, addio mio dolce amor!
subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, Edgar by Giacomo Puccini
role: Fidelia,  a young woman in love with Edgar
setting: the front of a fortress, Courtray, Flanders, late 19th century
range: C4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura D4 to F5
synopsis: Fidelia believes that Edgar has died as a great hero in battle.  At his funeral, she sings farewell to her one true love, asking him to wait for her in Heaven.

title: Nel villaggio d'Edgar
subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, Edgar by Giacomo Puccini
role: Fidelia,  a young woman in love with Edgar
setting: the front of a fortress, Courtray, Flanders, late 19th century
range: C4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura F4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Edgar has supposedly died as a hero in battle.  However, at his funeral, it is revealed that he was not quite as good as her was made out to be.  In fact, he apparently set fire to his house and wounded Frank in order to run off with the courtesan Tigrana.  As the mob cries out for his body to be thrown to the crows, his love Fidelia steps out and sings that, she too was from Edgar's village and knows that his heart and soul were pure even though he may have committed a few small sins.

title: Bella signora il pianto sciupa gli occhi
subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, Edgar by Giacomo Puccini
role: Edgar,  a young man in love with Fidelia
setting: the front of a fortress, Courtray, Flanders, late 19th century
range: G4 to G5. Tessitura A5 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Edgar, disguised as the monk presiding over his own funeral, tells Fidelia not to cry when his name is denounced as a sinner and a traitor to his country.

title: O lebbra, sozzura del mondo
subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, Edgar by Giacomo Puccini
role: Edgar,  a young man in love with Fidelia
setting: the front of a fortress, Courtray, Flanders, late 19th century
range: F3 to B5. Tessitura B4 to F#/Gb4
synopsis: Edgar has revealed that he is not, in fact, dead as previously stated in the opera.  He is alive and has witnessed his former lover Tigrana telling lies about him at his funeral for money.  He denounces her as a filthy leper and turns to his true love Fidelia saying that the illusions that had surrounded him before are now gone away.

title: Allein! Weh, ganz allein!
subtitle: from the one-act German opera, Elektra by Richard Strauss
role: Elektra (Electra),  daughter of Agamemnon and Klytemnestra
setting: the courtyard of the palace at Mycene, ancient Greece
range: C4 to C6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: Elektra explains the story of how Elektra's father was murdered by her mother and her lover Aegistheus.  She invokes his name and plans for revenge against her mother.  Her brother Orestes and Elektra have planned to murder her mother, after which they will dance around their dead bodies.

title: Ich hab's wie Feuer in der Brust
subtitle: from the one-act German opera, Elektra by Richard Strauss
role: Chrysothemis,  daughter of Agamemnon and Klytemnestra
setting: the courtyard of the palace at Mycene, ancient Greece
range: A#/Bb4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: Chrysothemis is tired of Elektra's plans for revenging their father's murder by their mother.  Instead, she wants to escape the palace and release the fires of love which are within her.

title: Wie stark du bist!
subtitle: from the one-act German opera, Elektra by Richard Strauss
role: Elektra (Electra),  daughter of Agamemnon and Klytemnestra
setting: the courtyard of the palace at Mycene, ancient Greece
range: D#/Eb4 to B6. Tessitura G4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: After hearing that her brother Orestes is dead, Elektra tries to convince Chrysothemis to kill their mother.  She flatters her, saying that she is very strong and beautiful and would be able to do the deed easily.  Plus, if she helped Elektra, Elektra would look after her.  She attempts to hold Chrysothemis there beside her but is not able.

title: Orest! Orest! Orest!
subtitle: from the one-act German opera, Elektra by Richard Strauss
role: Elektra (Electra),  daughter of Agamemnon and Klytemnestra
setting: the courtyard of the palace at Mycene, ancient Greece
range: D4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura G4 to A6
synopsis: Elektra has just met her brother Orestes, who she thought was dead.  In her joy, she cries out his name.  She tells him not to embrace her since she is dirty and no longer beautiful.  She explains that she gave up her beauty in order to work for revenge against her mother.  Now that Orestes has returned alive, that revenge will be soon in coming.

title: Come rugiada al cespite
subtitle: - Cavatina from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A deserted area in the mountains of Saragossa, Spain, 1519
range: G3 to A5. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: Ernani discloses his love for Elvira to his bandits and says that if he cannot have her, he will not be able to continue living.

title: O tu che l'alma adora
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Come rugiada al cespite from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A deserted area in the mountains of Saragossa, Spain, 1519
range: F3 to A5. Tessitura A4 to G4
synopsis: After disclosing his love for Elvira to his men in the first part of the aria, Ernani goes on in this cabaletta to talk to Elvira directly, even though she is not there.

title: Ernani, Ernani involami
subtitle: - Cavatina from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Elvira,  the niece and fiancee of Don Ruy Gomez
setting: Elvira's rooms in Don Ruy Gomez de Silva's apartments, Spain, 1519
range: A#/Bb4 to C6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: Elvira is in love with Ernani but is betrothed to her uncle Silva,  She wishes that he would go away and stop chasing her and leave her alone to think about Ernani, who she continues on to expound on.

title: Tutto sprezzo che d'Ernani
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Ernani, Ernani involami from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Elvira,  the niece and fiancee of Don Ruy Gomez
setting: Elvira's rooms in Don Ruy Gomez de Silva's apartments, Spain, 1519
range: C4 to C6. Tessitura E4 to A#/Bb6
synopsis: After her maids present her with presents from her uncle and betrothed Silva, Elvira declares that she does not care for any expensive gifts that don't remind her of Ernani.

title: Lo vedremo, veglio audace
subtitle: from Act II of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A hall in Don Ruy Gomez de Silva's castle, Spain, 1519
range: D3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura E3 to E4
synopsis: King Carlo has entered Silva's castle in search of the bandit Ernani.  He is sure that Silva is hiding Ernani somewhere inside but Silva denies it.  Carlo becomes angry and threatens to torture the information out of Silva who he believes is a traitor.  He finally offers him a choice of what to give him his head or the traitor Ernani

title: Vieni meco, soldi rose
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Lo vedremo, veglio audace from Act II of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A hall in Don Ruy Gomez de Silva's castle, Spain, 1519
range: F#/Gb3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura F#/Gb3 to F#/Gb4
synopsis: King Carlo has entered Silva's castle in search of the bandit Ernani.  He is sure that Silva is hiding Ernani somewhere inside but Silva denies it.  Carlo becomes angry and threatens to torture the information out of Silva, but retracts his offer when he sees Elvira, Silva's niece and fiancee.  He offers a choice for Silva give up Ernani or give up Elvira.  Silva gives up Elvira and Carlo sings passionately to her with a slight bit of menace added in.

title: Oh de'verd'anni miei
subtitle: - Cavatina from Act III of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: An underground vault holding the tomb of Charlemagne, Aix-la-Chapelle, 1519
range: D#/Eb3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Waiting to expose a conspiracy to murder him, Don Carlo sings to the tomb of Charlemagne of the glories and the vanities of the world.

title: O sommo Carlo
subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: An underground vault holding the tomb of Charlemagne, Aix-la-Chapelle, 1519
range: C3 to F4. Tessitura F3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: After capturing the conspirators who had planned to murder him, Carlo sings to the dead Emporer Charlemagne.

title: Odi il voto o grande Iddio
subtitle: - Added to the score in 1844 from Act II of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A hall in Don Ruy Gomez de Silva's castle, Spain, 1519
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Having sworn his services to Silva, Ernani sings to his dead father, swearing that he will avenge him with his fellow bandits.

title: Eldorado
subtitle: - No. 14A, Ballad from Act II of the English opera, Candide by Leonard Bernstein
role: Candide,  a bastard in a noble family
setting: Eldorado, 18th century
range: C#/Db3 to F4. Tessitura F3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Candide tells the story of Eldorado and of the riches that the lands hold.

title: Dear Boy
subtitle: - Appendix to the opera from Appendix of the English opera, Candide by Leonard Bernstein
range: B3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura E3 to D4
synopsis: Pangloss tells Candide of syphilus and how he caught it through the powers of Love

title: I am easily assimilated
subtitle: - No. 11, Tango from Act I of the English opera, Candide by Leonard Bernstein
setting: Buenos Aires, 18th century
range: D4 to F#/Gb5. Tessitura D4 to D5
synopsis: The Old Lady tells of her diverse backgrounds and how she can easily go back and forth between nationalities.

title: Je dis que rien ne m'pouvante
subtitle: from Act I of the French opera, Carmen by Georges Bizet
role: Micala,  a young girl from Don Jos's village
setting: A mountain pass
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Searching for Don José, who she still loves in spite of the smugglers, Micaëla finds herself alone in the mountains.  Frightened, she prays for courage.

title: Habanera ("L'amour est un oiseau rebelle")
subtitle: from Act I of the French opera, Carmen by Georges Bizet
setting: A square in Seville
range: D4 to F#/Gb5. Tessitura D4 to D5
synopsis: After appearing out of the cigarette factory, Carmen seductively sings about love and its unpredictable actions.

title: Seguidilla ("Prs des ramparts de Sville")
subtitle: from Act I of the French opera, Carmen by Georges Bizet
setting: A square in Seville
range: B4 to B6. Tessitura D4 to E5
synopsis: After Carmen is arrested for fighting another girl in the cigarette factory, Don Jose is assigned to watch her.  She sings that she wants to go to her friend Lillias Pastia's inn and insinuates that she would like him to go with her.

title: Card Aria ("En vain pour viter")
subtitle: from Act III of the French opera, Carmen by Georges Bizet
setting: A mountain pass.
range: B4 to F5. Tessitura B4 to D5
synopsis: Carmen reads her fortune from a deck of cards and finds that they predict death for her.  Again and again she tries but it still comes up death.   She then sings that fate is unavoidable for the cards never lie.

title: Flower Song ("La fleur que tu m'avais jete")
subtitle: from Act II of the French opera, Carmen by Georges Bizet
role: Don Jos,  a corporal of the dragoons (soldiers)
setting: The inn of Lillias Pastia
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Carmen and José have just reunited after José's stay in prison for releasing Carmen when he was supposed to be guarding her.  She has danced and played castanets for him but in the distance, he hears the call back to the barracks and he says he must go.  She becomes angry at him for leaving her.  Don Jose then responds by singing how the flower she threw to him kept him going throughout his stay at the prison.

title: Toreador Song ("Votre toast je peux vous le rendre")
subtitle: from Act I of the French opera, Carmen by Georges Bizet
setting: The inn of Lillias Pastia
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Escamillo, a great bullfighter, sings of his adventures in the bullring.

title: Les tringles des sistres tintaient
subtitle: - Chanson Bohemienne from Act II of the French opera, Carmen by Georges Bizet
setting: The inn of Lillias Pastia
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: With her friends Frasquita and Mercedes, Carmen sings a wild gyspy song about dancing and seduction to the joyous tavern crowd.

title: Siciliana (Lola, bianca come fior di spino)
subtitle: from Prelude of the Italian opera, Cavalleria Rusticana by Pietro Mascagni
setting: Easter Sunday in a Sicilian village, Italy, late 1800s
range: G#/Ab3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura C4 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: From offstage, Turiddu sings to his love, Lola, of her many virtues and what he would go through to be with her.

title: Il cavallo scalpita
subtitle: from the one-act Italian opera, Cavalleria Rusticana by Pietro Mascagni
setting: Easter Sunday in the main square of a Sicilian village, Italy, late 1800s
range: D#/Eb3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Alfio sings that, though the world is full of troubles, it doesn't bother him for he has a wonderful wife and a fun life.

title: Voi lo sapete
subtitle: - Romanza from the one-act Italian opera, Cavalleria Rusticana by Pietro Mascagni
setting: Easter Sunday in the main square of a Sicilian village, Italy, late 1800s
range: B4 to A6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: Santuzza tells Mamma Lucia that when her son left to join the Army, he promised to marry Lola.  When he came back, however, Lola had married someone else.  So, he fell in love with Santuzza which made Lola so jealous that she has stolen him away from Santuzza.

title: Fior di giaggiolo
subtitle: - Stornello from the one-act Italian opera, Cavalleria Rusticana by Pietro Mascagni
setting: Easter Sunday in the main square of a Sicilian village, Italy, late 1800s
range: D4 to G5. Tessitura G4 to E5
synopsis: Lola sings from offstage that there are a thousand beautiful angels in Heaven, but none are as handsome as her love Turiddu.

title: Brindisi (Viva il vino spumeggiante)
subtitle: - Drinking Song from the one-act Italian opera, Cavalleria Rusticana by Pietro Mascagni
setting: Easter Sunday in the main square of a Sicilian village, Italy, late 1800s
range: G4 to G5. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Turiddu sings a drinking song, praising wine that makes one's thoughts turn only to happiness.

title: Mamma, quel vino  generoso
subtitle: from the one-act Italian opera, Cavalleria Rusticana by Pietro Mascagni
setting: Easter Sunday in the main square of a Sicilian village, Italy, late 1800s
range: D#/Eb3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura A#/Bb4 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Turiddu has been challenged to a duel by Alfio.  He is drunk and does not believe that he will live through the duel.  He tells his mother that he is going out and asks her to take care of Santuzza if he doesn't come back.

title: In uomini, in soldati
subtitle: - No. 12 from Act I, Scene III of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Despina,  the serving maid of Dorabella and Fiordiligi
setting: the living room of Dorabella and Fiordiligi's house
range: C4 to A6. Tessitura F4 to F5
synopsis: After Dorabella declares that she cannot live while Ferrando is gone because of her grief, Despina tells her mistresses that one cannot expect men, especially soldiers, to be faithful.  She goes on to describe men as creatures that use women for pleasure and can change at any moment.  Despina states that, therefore, women should only be faithful to their own self.

title: Come scoglio
subtitle: - No. 14 from Act I, Scene III of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Fiordiligi,  sister of Dorabella and fiancee of Guglielmo
setting: the living room of Dorabella and Fiordiligi's house
range: A4 to C6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: Two mysterious Albanians that are really Guglielmo and Ferrando in disguise have shown up at the sisters' door accompanied by Don Alfonso.  The two men attempt to woo the sisters.  Fiordiligi will have nothing to do with it, though, and, in this difficult aria, declares her loyalty to Guglielmo and asks the strangers to stop attempting to win them.

title: Una donna a quindici anni
subtitle: - No. 19 from Act II, Scene I of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Despina,  the serving maid of Dorabella and Fiordiligi
setting: the dressing room of Dorabella and Fiordiligi
range: D4 to B6. Tessitura D4 to G5
synopsis: After encouraging the sisters to have the Albanians back to their house, Despina sings this aria, saying that a girl of fifteen should know how to flirt successfully.  She should be able to lead on any man and lie when needed.

title: Per piet
subtitle: - No. 25, Rondo from Act II, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Cos fan tutte by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Fiordiligi,  sister of Dorabella and fiancee of Guglielmo
setting: the garden of Dorabella and Fiordiligi
range: A#/Bb4 to B6. Tessitura B4 to G5
synopsis: After having begun to feel passion for one of the Albanians, Fiordiligi apologizes to the absent Guglielmo, her love.  She sings that her feelings have betrayed him and that she will hide this terrible incident from him.

title: O messager de Dieu
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 1 of the French opera, Thas by Jules Massenet
setting: An desert oasis in Egypt, 14th century
range: D4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Athanal has forced Thas to walk through the desert to an oasis with a nunnery.  Although she is exhausted, she praises him as a messenger from God that revives her soul even as the desert has sapped her strength.

title: Tu sais,  Palmon
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 2 of the French opera, Thas by Jules Massenet
setting: Cenobite place on the banks of the Nile, late 14th century
range: C3 to F4. Tessitura F3 to E4
synopsis: Athanal tells Palmon, an old monk, that he has brought Thas back to God from sin.  Since he left her, though, he has felt no peace.  She fills his dreams and is as beautiful as Helen of Troy and Venus the goddess of Love.

title: Willow Song (Willow where we met together)
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the English opera, The Ballad of Baby Doe by Douglas Moore
role: Elizabeth Doe (Baby Doe),  the wife of a miner
setting: outside of the Clarendon Hotel, Leadville, Colorado, 1880
range: F4 to D6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: Baby Doe sits at a piano, playing and singing for herself.  The song she sings sounds like an ordinary song about lost love.  However, she is actually singing about her broken marriage with Harvey Doe and how it fell apart.

title: Warm as the autumn light
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the English opera, The Ballad of Baby Doe by Douglas Moore
role: Horace Tabor,  mayor of Leadville and owner of the Matchless Mine
setting: outside of the Clarendon Hotel, Leadville, Colorado, 1880
range: B3 to E4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to C#/Db4
synopsis: Tabor has just overheard Baby Doe singing.  He then goes to meet her and tells her how her beautiful singing made him think of his own youth and what he left behind when he came out to Colorado from New Hampshire.  He implies tenderly that he could find some of these lost things again in her.

title: Letter Song (Dearest Mama)
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 4 of the English opera, The Ballad of Baby Doe by Douglas Moore
role: Elizabeth Doe (Baby Doe),  the wife of a miner
setting: lobby of the Clarendon Hotel, Leadville, Colorado, 1880
range: E4 to C#/Db6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Baby Doe writes a letter to her mother, telling her that her marriage to Harvey Doe, the miner, is over.  She goes on to tell her then that she has found her soulmate in Horace Tabor and they both love each other equally.  However, Tabor is married and, torn between her love and what is right, she feels that she must leave.

title: Gold Aria (Gold is a fine thing)
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 6 of the English opera, The Ballad of Baby Doe by Douglas Moore
role: Elizabeth Doe (Baby Doe),  the wife of a miner
setting: Willard Hotel, Washington, D.C., 1880
range: E4 to C#/Db6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: After there is much distress and arguing about whether the silver standard should be repealed or not, Baby Doe tells her view on the subject, saying that gold is only flashy.  However, silver is the core of the dreams and hopes that hold the country together.

title: The fine ladies walk with their heads
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the English opera, The Ballad of Baby Doe by Douglas Moore
role: Elizabeth Doe (Baby Doe),  the wife of a miner
setting: balcony outside the Governor's Ball at the Windsor Hotel, Denver, Colorado, 1893
range: D#/Eb4 to A6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: At the ball, Baby Doe and her mother are treated as second-class citizens by the other women at the ball.  They go out on to the balcony to get away from the snobbery and Baby Doe declares that the reason that other women look down upon her is because they wish they had what she had.  What she has is the true love of Horace Tabor, which she goes on to say is the most valuable thing that she could own.

title: Turn tail and run then
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 2 of the English opera, The Ballad of Baby Doe by Douglas Moore
role: Horace Tabor,  mayor of Leadville and owner of the Matchless Mine
setting: club room in Denver, Colorado, 1895
range: A3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Tabor's cronies have decided to support William McKinley for president instead of the party's choice of William Jennings Bryan.  Tabor tries to convince them to stay loyal, believing that Bryan will bring back the silver standard that made Tabor and his cronies rich.  When they refuse to go along with him, Tabor angrily accuses them of being turncoats and declares that the smart and free men in the country will make up for them.

title: Augusta!  How can you turn away?
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 4 of the English opera, The Ballad of Baby Doe by Douglas Moore
role: Augusta Tabor,  wife of Horace Tabor
setting: Augusta's study, 1896
range: B4 to G#/Ab5. Tessitura F4 to F5
synopsis: Baby Doe's mother has come to Augusta, asking her to help her ex-husband Horace Tabor, who left her for Baby Doe.  Tabor has lost all of his money and can hardly support himself.  Augusta sends her away, declining to help the couple.  However, after she leaves, Augusta wonders why she doesn't run to help the man that she once loved.

title: Always through the changing of sun and shadow
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 5 of the English opera, The Ballad of Baby Doe by Douglas Moore
role: Elizabeth Doe (Baby Doe),  the wife of a miner
setting: stage of the Tabor Grand Theater, Leadville, Colorado, 1899
range: D#/Eb4 to B6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: As her beloved husband Tabor lies dying, Baby Doe tells him that she will always remain faithful to him, even letting a part of her go with him as his dies.

title: Kdybych se co takovho  (Ah my darling, we could grow together)
subtitle: from Act I of the Czech opera, The Bartered Bride (Prodan Nevesta) by Bedrich Smetana
role: Marenka,  daughter of Krusina and Ludmilla
setting: spring in a Bohemian village, Bohemia
range: D4 to A6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: Marenka and Jenik are in love but Marenka's parents have promised her to another man.  Marenka has decided that she will refuse to go along with it.  She notices, however, that Jenik seems uneasy.  Suspecting that there might be something he is hiding from her, she tells him that she would be heart-broken if she ever learned of another woman in his life.  She knows little of his past and wonders if that might mean that he has already left one sweetheart.

title: M ma-ma-ticka (Nnnnow, my dear)
subtitle: from Act II of the Czech opera, The Bartered Bride (Prodan Nevesta) by Bedrich Smetana
role: Vasek,  son of Micha and Hata
setting: inside an inn in a Bohemian village, Bohemia
range: G3 to A5. Tessitura G3 to E4
synopsis: Vasek enters the inn when it is empty.  He mentions, shyly and stuttering, that his mother has told him firmly to win the wife that she has picked out for him.  Unbeknownst to him, the woman picked out to be his wife is Marenka, the beloved of Jenik who is Vasek's brother.

title: Jak mozn verit (Soon now, my dearest)
subtitle: from Act II of the Czech opera, The Bartered Bride (Prodan Nevesta) by Bedrich Smetana
role: Jenik,  son of Micha by his first marriage
setting: inside an inn in a Bohemian village, Bohemia
range: G3 to A5. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: Jenik and the marriage broker, Kecal, have been bargaining.  Kecal wants Jenik to give up any claim to his beloved, Marenka.  Jenik finally agrees but only if he receives a large sum of money and under the condition that Marenka marries the elder son of Micha.  Kecal thinks he has made a good deal because the elder son of Micha is presumed dead.  However, he doesn't know that Jenik is really Micha's eldest son.  After Kecal leaves, Jenik gloats over his clever victory, saying that anyone who could expect him to sell Marenka is a fool.  To him, Marenka is too valuable to be sold for any amount of money.

title: To-to mi v hlave lez (Oh, how ddddoubts fill me)
subtitle: from Act III of the Czech opera, The Bartered Bride (Prodan Nevesta) by Bedrich Smetana
role: Vasek,  son of Micha and Hata
setting: spring in a Bohemian village, Bohemia
range: E3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura F3 to F#/Gb4
synopsis: Vasek is upset because he cannot find the wonderful girl that he met earlier.  She advised him against marrying Marenka, the wife that had been chosen for him, telling him that there is another girl that would be better for him.  However, Vasek finds that he is obsessed with the unknown girl to the point where he cannot think of anything else.  He does not know that the girl he talked to was actually Marenka.

title: Och, jaky zal!Ten lsky sen (How can I liveHow strange and dead is everything here)
subtitle: from Act III of the Czech opera, The Bartered Bride (Prodan Nevesta) by Bedrich Smetana
role: Marenka,  daughter of Krusina and Ludmilla
setting: spring in a Bohemian village, Bohemia
range: F4 to A6. Tessitura G4 to F5
synopsis: Marenka believes that her love, Jenik, has betrayed her by selling the rights to marry her to another person.  As it turns out, Jenik has actually sold the rights to marry Marenka to himself in order to legalize their relationship.  However, he neglects to tell Marenka this and she feels completely betrayed.  She still hasn't heard about it from Jenik himself so she hasn't completely given up on him.  However, she still feels that her dream of living happily ever after has been completely crushed.

title: A Soldier's Life

range: G2 to E4. Tessitura Has not been entered yet.

subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the English opera, The Bohemian Girl by Michael William Balfe

range: D#/Eb4 to G5. Tessitura Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Arline, daughter of Count Arnheim, has been raised in a gypsy camp.  She has no conscious memory of her father, from whom she was separated when a child. She tells Thaddeus, a Polish exile who has also been living with the gypsies for several years, of a dream she had.

title: Bliss forever past
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the English opera, The Bohemian Girl by Michael William Balfe

Then she expresses her sorrow in a ballad.

range: F#/Gb3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to F#/Gb4

subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Fanciulla del West by Giacomo Puccini

title: Oh, se sapeste

She finds joy, peace, and excitement in the natural beauty of the Sierra Nevada Mountains and the meadows and valleys that lie in-between them.

title: Or son sei mesi
subtitle: from Act II of the Italian opera, La Fanciulla del West by Giacomo Puccini

He responds that he came to rob her but was unable to after seeing her.  He then goes on to tell her of his life.  His father was a bandit  but when his father died six months ago, Johnson had to support them by taking over his father's gang.  After seeing Minnie, he no longer wants to be a thief.

subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, La Fanciulla del West by Giacomo Puccini

Although he doesn't know anything about her, he does know that she is young and beautiful like an angel and that he cannot get her out of his thoughts.

Lonore is also taken with Fernand but, unfortunately, she is the mistress of the king and tells him that any relationship between the two of them would end badly.  To help him out, though, she has acquired him a commission in the king's army.  He exults over this chance, anticipating the impressive deeds that he will accomplish.  He hopes that his imminent glory will cause Lonore to change her mind about their relationship.

Fernand is granted a reward by the king for his valor in battle, and not knowing that she is the king's "favorite", Fernand asks for her hand in marriage, which the king grants. Leonore is willing to sacrifice her own happiness to ensure Fernand's, and determines to let him know the truth.

Thinking that his bride is pure, he prepares to marry her.  However, before she appears, he finds out that she has been the lover of the King.  With his heart broken, he returns to the monastery and mourns for the betrayal of his love and the loss of Lonore.

libretto: Jean Francois Bayard and J.H. Vernoyde Saint-Georges

When the Marquise catches Marie and Tonio together, she tells Tonio to leave but Tonio first explains the depths of his love for Marie.  He explains that he could not continue living if he could not be with her.

subtitle: - No. 3, Srnade from Act I of the French opera, La Juive by Jacques Franois Fromental Halvy

title: Tandis qu'il sommeille
subtitle: - No. 13 from Act III of the French opera, La Juive by Jacques Franois Fromental Halvy

subtitle: - No. 15, Bolro from Act III of the French opera, La Juive by Jacques Franois Fromental Halvy

title: Rachel! quand du Seigneur
subtitle: - No. 22 from Act IV of the French opera, La Juive by Jacques Franois Fromental Halvy

Elazar knows he can save her life by revealing this fact, but he is unable to reconcile his Jewish faith with forcing his daughter to change her faith.

subtitle: - No. 18c, Maldiction from Act III of the French opera, La Juive by Jacques Franois Fromental Halvy

She despairs inwardly, though, because she is not pure and innocent.  Before she met Ruggero, she was just a step above a prostitute.

subtitle: from Intermezzo Secondo of the Italian opera, La Serva Padrona by Giovanni Pergolesi

subtitle: - No. 4, Recitative and Cavatina from Act I of the Italian opera, La Sonnambula by Vincenzo Bellini
role: Amina,  an orphan who has been adopted by Teresa

range: D4 to C6. Tessitura G4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: Amina thanks all the attendees to her wedding to Elvino, saying that they have made her life happy.  She then thanks her mother for watching over her.  She goes on, saying that this day is beautiful like the flowers and that all nature rejoices for her love.

title: Sovra il sen la man mi posa
subtitle: - No. 4, Cabaletta to Care compagneCome per me serena from Act I of the Italian opera, La Sonnambula by Vincenzo Bellini
role: Amina,  an orphan who has been adopted by Teresa
setting: The village green of a village in Switzerland, early 19th century
range: D#/Eb4 to C#/Db6. Tessitura G#/Ab4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: On her wedding day, Amina sings that she is so filled with joy that she cannot find the words to tell how happy she is.

title: Vi ravviso, o luoghi ameni
subtitle: - No. 6, Cavatina from Act I of the Italian opera, La Sonnambula by Vincenzo Bellini
role: Count Rodolfo,  Lord of the village
setting: The village green of a village in Switzerland, early 19th century
range: G2 to C#/Db4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to C#/Db4
synopsis: Count Rodolfo has come in disguise to stay a night at Lisa's inn.  He speaks to himself of the days of his youth when all was tranquil and serene.  He regrets that he will never be able to recapture them.

title: Tu che i miseri conforti
subtitle: - No. 9 from Act II, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Tancredi by Gioacchino Rossini
setting: a gallery in Argirio's palace, Syracuse, Sicily, 1005 AD
