synopsis: Amenaide has been condemned to die for refusing to marry Orbazzano to unite the city against the Saracens.  Isuara, however, still believes in her and prays for God to save her.

title: Di mia vita infeliceNo, che il morir non
subtitle: - No. 10, Scena and Cavatina from Act II, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Tancredi by Gioacchino Rossini
setting: prison, Syracuse, Sicily, 1005 AD
range: D4 to G#/Ab5. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: As Amenaide sits in jail, condemned to die for refusing to marry Orbazzano to unite the city against the Saracens, she hopes that her love will realize after she is dead that she was innocent of betraying his heart.  After all, she is really dying because she refused to be unfaithful to him.

title: Gran Dio!Giusto Dio che umile adoro
subtitle: - No. 12, Recit. and Aria from Act II, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Tancredi by Gioacchino Rossini
setting: prison, Syracuse, Sicily, 1005 AD
range: C#/Db4 to C6. Tessitura G#/Ab4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: Amenaide has been condemned to die for refusing to marry Orbazzano to unite the city against the Saracens.  However, her father and Tancredi both do not want her to die.  As Tancredi leaves to prove her innocence, she prays that he will forgive her and be successful in his quest.

title: Torni alfin ridente, e bella
subtitle: - No. 15 from Act II, Scene 3 of the Italian opera, Tancredi by Gioacchino Rossini
setting: the main square of Syracuse, Sicily, 1005 AD
range: G4 to A6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Roggiero worries if his friend's love, Amenaide, is truly faithful to him.

title: Dove son ioAh! che scordar non so
subtitle: - No. 16-I, Scena and Cavatina from Act II, Scene 4 of the Italian opera, Tancredi by Gioacchino Rossini
role: Tancredi,  banished member of the royal family
setting: the mountains outside of Syracuse, Sicily, 1005 AD
range: B4 to D5. Tessitura D4 to D5
synopsis: Tancredi has gone off to fight the Saracens and prove his love's innocence of treason.  However, he doesn't really believe it himself.  He thinks that she has betrayed him by agreeing to marry another, even though she later didn't go through with it and was sentenced to die because of her refusal.  However, as he looks out into the surrounding mountains, he realizes that he still loves her.

title: Or che dici? or che rispondi?
subtitle: - part of No. 16-iv from Act II, Scene 4 of the Italian opera, Tancredi by Gioacchino Rossini
role: Tancredi,  banished member of the royal family
setting: the mountains outside of Syracuse, Sicily, 1005 AD
range: B4 to G5. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to C5
synopsis: Tancredi has gone off to fight the Saracens and prove his love's innocence of treason.  He believes that Amenaide has betrayed his love but her father proves that she was always faithful to him.  Before leading the troops into battle, he tells Amenaide that he is still angry but that he believes her and still loves her.

title: Dir tne Lob!
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the German opera, Tannhuser by Richard Wagner
setting: the Venusberg, near Eisenach, early 1200's
range: E3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura A4 to F#/Gb4
synopsis: Tannhuser is inside the mountain of Venus, surrounded by nymphs and satyrs.  He worships the goddess of Love and expresses his praise for her in a hymn.  The hymn's verses are divided by conversation between Venus and Tannhuser.

title: Geliebter, komm!
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the German opera, Tannhuser by Richard Wagner
setting: the Venusberg, near Eisenach, early 1200's
range: F#/Gb4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Tannhuser has expressed his desire to leave Venus's loving arms.  This upsets her and she tries to convince him to stay.

title: Als du im khnem Sange uns betrittest
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 4 of the German opera, Tannhuser by Richard Wagner
setting: the valley of the Wartburg, near Eisenach, early 1200's
range: D3 to E4. Tessitura F#/Gb3 to E4
synopsis: Tannhuser and Wolfram meet as Tannhuser is traveling to Rome as a pilgrim.  Since Tannhuser has been missing for some time, his love Elisabeth has been mourning him.  Wolfram tells him this, attempting to get him to come back to the Wartburg.

title: Dich, theure Halle
subtitle: from Act II of the German opera, Tannhuser by Richard Wagner
setting: the Hall of Song, near Eisenach, early 1200's
range: D#/Eb4 to B6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Elisabeth hears that her love, Tannhuser, is coming back to the Hall of Song, which is the site of many of his triumphs in singing competitions.  She enters the Hall and greets it brilliantly and with great joy.

title: Allmcht'ge Jungfrau
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 1 of the German opera, Tannhuser by Richard Wagner
setting: the valley of the Wartburg, near Eisenach, early 1200's
range: D4 to F#/Gb5. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to E5
synopsis: Tannhuser, after praising the joys of sex in a singing competition, has left on a pilgrimage to Rome, leaving his love Elisabeth behind.  He is due to arrive back soon.  However, he isn't with the group of pilgrims that he left with and, afraid for his safety, Elisabeth prays to the Virgin Mary for Tannhuser's redemption.  She also prays that she may soon be freed from her unhappy life.

title: O du mein holder Abendstern
subtitle: - Song of the Evening Star from Act III, Scene 2 of the German opera, Tannhuser by Richard Wagner
setting: the valley of the Wartburg, near Eisenach, early 1200's
range: B3 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: As the night falls, Wolfram sings an ode to the evening star.

title: Inbrunst im Herzen
subtitle: from Act III, Scene 3 of the German opera, Tannhuser by Richard Wagner
setting: the valley of the Wartburg, near Eisenach, early 1200's
range: E3 to A5. Tessitura G3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: After returning on his pilgrimage to Rome, Tannhuser meets Wolfram on the road to the Warteburg.  When Wolfram asks him about his journey, Tannhuser replies with the entire long tale.  He went to Rome through great hardships, only to be told by the Pope that he would have no forgiveness.

title: Blick' ich umher
subtitle: from Act II of the German opera, Tannhuser by Richard Wagner
setting: the Hall of Song, near Eisenach, early 1200's
range: D3 to D#/Eb4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to D4
synopsis: To start the tournament of song which has as its prize the hand of Elisabeth, Wolfram sings an ode praising the virtues of holy and righteous love.

title: Hlas, enfant encore
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 1 of the French opera, Thas by Jules Massenet
setting: Cenobite place on the banks of the Nile, late 14th century
range: C#/Db3 to F4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Athanal returns to his monastery and hears the other monks talking about a courtesan named Thas who has made a name for herself in Alexandria, the nearby city.  Athanal realizes that he knew this courtesan before he became a monk and realizes that he actually entertained the notion of hiring her "services" at one time.  He realizes now that it is his mission to bring her back to God.

title: Toi qui mis la piti
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 1 of the French opera, Thas by Jules Massenet
setting: Cenobite place on the banks of the Nile, late 14th century
range: C3 to F4. Tessitura E3 to E4
synopsis: After Athanal has a dream in which the enticing courtesan Thas danced erotically for him, he takes the  dream a sign that he should go into Alexandria and turn Thas back to God's guidance.  He swears this to his god.

title: Voil donc la terrible cit
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the French opera, Thas by Jules Massenet
setting: Nicias's house with terrace with view of Alexandria, Egypt, late 14th century
range: D#/Eb3 to F4. Tessitura E3 to C4
synopsis: Athanal arrives in Alexandria in an attempt to save the soul of the courtesan Thas.  He gazes upon the city and remembers its faults and temptations.  He knows he is no longer tempted by them and therefore hates the city for its sins and asks God and the angels to purify the city.

title: Qui te fiat si svre
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 2 of the French opera, Thas by Jules Massenet
setting: Thas's house, Alexandria, Egypt, late 14th century
range: D#/Eb4 to G#/Ab5. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to F5
synopsis: Athanal meets Thas as her devoted customers surround her.  He says that her seductive words are blasphemous and in return, she asks him why he is so unhappy.  After all, hasn't he felt the desire to be loved and kissed?  What possibly could have made him unhappy?  She asks him to sit down with her and stay with her for awhile.

title: Dis-moi que je suis belle
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the French opera, Thas by Jules Massenet
setting: Thas's house, Alexandria, Egypt, late 14th century
range: D4 to D6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: Thas sits alone in her room at her mirror, gazing into it.  She worries about getting old and asks her mirror to tell her that she is still beautiful and that she will be beautiful until the day she dies.

title: L'amour est une vertu rare
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 2 of the French opera, Thas by Jules Massenet
setting: In front of Thas's house, Alexandria, Egypt, late 14th century
range: D4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura A5 to F5
synopsis: Thas has consented to go off with Athanal the monk and give up her sinful ways.  She wants to keep a small statute of Eros, though.  She tells Athanal that love is precious and that it should be revered like the small statue given to her by Nicias when he still loved her.

title: Isabella's Aria ("Yes, that wild fire in your heart")
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 3 of the English opera, Blake by Leslie Adams
role: Isabella Ballard,  house guest on the Stevens plantation
setting: a plantation in the Deep South, the United States, early 1860s
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Isabella sings a sharp, dramatic deunciation of Miranda for being too bold and proud, vowing, "...the ashes of your soul will warm my heart!"

title: My new-found friends
subtitle: from Act IV of the English opera, Blake by Leslie Adams
role: Blake,  30 year-old slave on a southern plantation
setting: the Great Dismal Swamp, southern Virginia, 1861
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Blake responds to his supporters after being initiated into a brotherhood fellowship in this arioso.

title: Varlaam's Song (kak vo gorode blo vo kazani)
subtitle: - from Act I, Scene 2 of the Russian opera, Boris Godunov by Modest Mussorgsky
setting: an inn on the Lithuanian border with Russia, 1603
range: F#/Gb3 to F4. Tessitura F#/Gb3 to F4
synopsis: Somewhat under the effect of the wine, Varlaam tells everyone in the inn all about his fighting prowess and his bravery in the battle of Kazan in the army of Ivan the Terrible.

title: Song of the Parrot (Popinka nash sidel)
subtitle: - from Act II of the Russian opera, Boris Godunov by Modest Mussorgsky
setting: a room in the Tsar's chambers in the Kremlin, Moscow, Russia, 1603
range: C#/Db4 to D#/Eb5. Tessitura E4 to C#/Db5
synopsis: In order to bring some happiness to the Nurse and his sister Xenia, Fyodor sings a song.  The song he sings is about his parrot which he has named Popinka.  The song explains how the parrot was annoying the wetnurse as well as Fyodor's father, Boris.

title: Song of the Gnat (Kak komar drova pubil)
subtitle: - from Act II of the Russian opera, Boris Godunov by Modest Mussorgsky
role: An Old Nurse,  the caretaker for the children of Boris Godunov
setting: a room in the Tsar's chambers in the Kremlin, Moscow, Russia, 1603
range: B4 to F#/Gb5. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to C#/Db5
synopsis: The Nurse sings a song about a gnat that is killed by a marauding dragonfly.  She sings the song to cheer up Xenia, whose fiance has recently died.  It doesn't really make her feel any better though.

title: Skorvit dusha!
subtitle: - from Prologue, Scene 2 of the Russian opera, Boris Godunov by Modest Mussorgsky
setting: the courtyard in the Kremlin, Moscow, Russia, 1598
range: D#/Eb3 to F4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to D4
synopsis: After being crowned Tsar of Russia, Boris Godunov offers a sincere prayer to the former tsars to ask for wisdom and good judgement as he begins his reign.

title: Song of the Drake (Pai mala ja siza selyeznja)
subtitle: - from Act I, Scene 2 of the Russian opera, Boris Godunov by Modest Mussorgsky
setting: an inn on the Lithuanian border with Russia, 1603
range: C#/Db4 to E5. Tessitura D4 to D5
synopsis: The innkeeper sings a little song about the duck that she caught and what she plans to do with it.  From its suggestive nature, it is pretty obvious that the "duck" is really a man.

title: Monologue of Boris (Dostig ja vsshei vlasti)
subtitle: - from Act II of the Russian opera, Boris Godunov by Modest Mussorgsky
setting: a room in the Tsar's chambers in the Kremlin, Moscow, Russia, 1603
range: A#/Bb3 to E4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Boris pours out his thoughts to his son.  He is now in his sixth year of rule with all the power he ever dreamed about but he is not happy.  He is upset that his daughter's fiance died before the wedding.  He is also upset that he was not able to alleviate some of the suffering and discontent that rages through his kingdom.  Finally, he is regretful that the route to the throne was won by the death of the previous Tsar's child half-brother Dmitri.

title: The Clock Scene (Uf, tja zhelo!)
subtitle: - from Act II of the Russian opera, Boris Godunov by Modest Mussorgsky
setting: a room in the Tsar's chambers in the Kremlin, Moscow, Russia, 1603
range: B3 to E4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Boris is told by Prince Shuisky that a rival to his throne has appeared and it seems that it is a man pretending to be Dmitri, the half-brother of the previous Tsar who was killed in order to facilitate Boris's rise to the throne.  Although Shuisky assures Boris that the real Dmitri is dead, Boris is overcome with the possibility that Dmitri has come back from the dead to haunt him.  As the chimes of a clock are struck, Boris imagines that he sees the ghost of Dmitri.  In horror he falls to the floor and prays for forgiveness.

title: Marina's Aria (Skushno Marina!)
subtitle: - from Act III, Scene 1 of the Russian opera, Boris Godunov by Modest Mussorgsky
setting: at the governor's castle in Sandomir, Poland, 1603
range: B4 to G#/Ab5. Tessitura E4 to E5
synopsis: Marina's attendants sing songs to her to amuse her but she tells them that they are merely boring.  She longs for excitement and power.  In particular, she believes that she will find this through Dmitri, the pretender to the Russian throne.  Through him, she hopes to gain power over all of Russia.

title: Pimen's Aria (Smirenni inok)
subtitle: - from Act IV, Scene 1 (Scene 2 in complete version) of the Russian opera, Boris Godunov by Modest Mussorgsky
role: Pimen,  an old monk and companion of Grigory the Pretender
setting: the council room in the Kremlin, Moscow, Russia, 1605
range: D3 to E4. Tessitura E3 to D4
synopsis: Pimen tells a story about a blind old shepherd that was told to pray at the tomb of the murdered half-brother of the previous Tsar, Dmitri.  When he did so, his sight was restored.

title: Death of Boris (Prashchai moy sn)
subtitle: - from Act IV, Scene 1 (Scene 2 in complete version) of the Russian opera, Boris Godunov by Modest Mussorgsky
setting: the council room in the Kremlin, Moscow, Russia, 1605
range: A#/Bb3 to E4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to D4
synopsis: Boris is stricken by the mention of the return of Dmitri, the murdered previous heir to the throne.  As he lays dying, he commands his son Fyodor to rule over Russia in a just and cautious manner.  He prays that his children remain safe.

title: Je vais le voir
subtitle: - No. 3 from Act I of the French opera, Batrice et Bndict by Hector Berlioz
libretto: Hector Berlioz ,  from Shakespeare's Much Ado about Nothing

range: D4 to B6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to G5
synopsis: Hro looks forward to seeing her love, Claudio.  He is to return soon from a victorious battle against an army of invading Moors.

title: Ah! je vais l'aimer
subtitle: - No. 7, Rondo from Act I of the French opera, Batrice et Bndict by Hector Berlioz
libretto: Hector Berlioz ,  from Shakespeare's Much Ado about Nothing

synopsis: Bndict's friend Claudio and his general Don Pedro have encouraged Bndict to get married.  However, he would much rather remain a bachelor forever.  He soon realizes that his love for Batrice may not let him follow the path of an unmarried man.  This is especially difficult since he and Batrice have never done anything but arguel.

title: Le vin de Syracuse
subtitle: - No. 9, Improvisation from Act II of the French opera, Batrice et Bndict by Hector Berlioz
libretto: Hector Berlioz ,  from Shakespeare's Much Ado about Nothing
setting: a ballroom in the palace of Lonato, Messina, Sicily
range: B3 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Somarone starts a drinking song with the others celebrating the victory over the Moors.

title: Il m'en souvient
subtitle: - No. 10 from Act II of the French opera, Batrice et Bndict by Hector Berlioz
libretto: Hector Berlioz ,  from Shakespeare's Much Ado about Nothing
setting: a ballroom in the palace of Lonato, Messina, Sicily
range: C4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura F4 to G5
synopsis: Batrice realizes that Bndict has fallen in love with her.  Although she acts like she doesn't care for him at all, she realizes that she is feeling increasing affection for him too.  She attempts to figure out whether it is love and if she can avoid it.

title: It Must be So
subtitle: - No. 3A, Song from Act I of the English opera, Candide by Leonard Bernstein
role: Candide,  a bastard in a noble family
setting: Westphalia, 18th century
range: G3 to E4. Tessitura G3 to E4
synopsis: After the castle of Thunder-ten-Tronck, the home Candide has known forever, is destroyed along with its inhabitants, Candide decides that he must head out on his own.  He does not look forward to leaving all he knew, but tries to find whatever good he can find.

title: It Must be Me
subtitle: - No. 5, Song from Act I of the English opera, Candide by Leonard Bernstein
role: Candide,  a bastard in a noble family
setting: Lisbon, 18th century
range: G3 to E4. Tessitura G3 to E4
synopsis: An earthquake has destroyed Lisbon and Candide is sentenced to hang for heresy along with his friend Pangloss.  Believing that there is good in the world, Candide decides that it must be his fault that life is not going the way he wants it.

title: Glitter and be gay
subtitle: - No. 7 from Act I of the English opera, Candide by Leonard Bernstein
setting: Paris, France, 18th century
range: D4 to D#/Eb6. Tessitura G#/Ab4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: After escaping the war that destroyed her family, Cunegonde is forced to maintain her lifestyle by sharing herself with several important Parisians.  She sings that she must  conceal her unhappiness by laughter and cheerful demeanor.

title: My Love
subtitle: - No. 10, Serenade from Act I of the English opera, Candide by Leonard Bernstein
setting: Buenos Aires, 18th century
range: D3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura G3 to F4
synopsis: The Governor has fallen in love with Cunegonde and tells her that they should be together while love remains.  After all, love is fleeting and will be gone in a week after he has enjoyed her.

title: Sprezzo la vita ne pi m'alletta
subtitle: - Cabaletta to Odi il voto o grande Iddio from Act II of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: A hall in Don Ruy Gomez de Silva's castle, Spain, 1519
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After singing the first part of this aria to his dead father, Ernani enters into this cabaletta singing of the vengeance he will exact for his father's death.

title: Infelice!..e tuo credevi
subtitle: - Cavatina from Act I, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, Ernani by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Don Ruy Gomez de Silva,  a Spanish grandee
setting: Elvira's rooms in Don Ruy Gomez de Silva's apartments, Spain, 1519
range: G2 to F4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Silva has entered his niece and fiancee Elvira's room to find both Ernani and Carlo inside.  He is shocked at this and laments self-pityingly.

title: Olga's Aria (Ja nye sposobna k grusti tomnoy)
subtitle: - from Act I, Scene 1 of the Russian opera, Eugene Onegin by Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky
libretto: Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky and Konstantin Shilovsky ,  after Pushkin's poem
role: Olga,  daughter of Madame Larina and sister of Tatiana
setting: twilight in the garden on Madame Larina's estate, St. Petersburg, Russia, late 1700s
range: A4 to E5. Tessitura C4 to C5
synopsis: When her sister comments that folk songs sung by the harvesters make her think of places far away from the estate, Olga responds that she has a different reaction when she hears the songs.  Dreaming about other places does absolutely nothing for her.  Instead, the songs just make her want to dance along with the peasants.

title: Lensky's Arioso (Ja lyublyu vas)
subtitle: - from Act I, Scene 1 of the Russian opera, Eugene Onegin by Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky
libretto: Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky and Konstantin Shilovsky ,  after Pushkin's poem
role: Lensky,  fiance of Olga and friend of Onegin
setting: twilight in the garden on Madame Larina's estate, St. Petersburg, Russia, late 1700s
range: D#/Eb3 to A5. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Lensky meets his fiancee, Olga, for the first time and is immediately captivated by her.  Unable to contain his feelings, he pours out his love to her.

title: Tatiana's Letter Scene (Ruskai pogibnu)
subtitle: - from Act I, Scene 2 of the Russian opera, Eugene Onegin by Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky
libretto: Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky and Konstantin Shilovsky ,  after Pushkin's poem
role: Tatiana,  daughter of Madame Larina and sister of Olga
setting: Tatiana's bedroom in Madame Larina's house, St. Petersburg, Russia, late 1700s
range: D4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura G4 to F5
synopsis: Tatiana decides that the only way to express her love for Onegin is to write him a letter in which she explains her feelings towards him.  As she writes, she discovers more and more about the depth and strength of her love for him.

title: Onegin's Aria (Kogda b zhizn domashnim krugom)
subtitle: - from Act I, Scene 3 of the Russian opera, Eugene Onegin by Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky
libretto: Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky and Konstantin Shilovsky ,  after Pushkin's poem
role: Eugene Onegin,  friend of Lensky with first name often spelled "Yevgeny"
setting: the gardens on Madame Larina's estate, St. Petersburg, Russia, late 1700s
range: D3 to F4. Tessitura F3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Tatiana has written Onegin a letter in which she declares her love for him.  Onegin, however, doesn't want Tatiana.  Although he does not make fun of her love, he does tell the truth that he does not love her in anything but a brotherly way.  He asks her to find another man who would return her love.

title: Triquet's Song (Kakoi pre krasni etot den)
subtitle: - from Act II, Scene 1 of the Russian opera, Eugene Onegin by Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky
libretto: Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky and Konstantin Shilovsky ,  after Pushkin's poem
role: Monsieur Triquet,  an old Frenchman employed by Madame Larina as a tutor
setting: a simple ballroom in Madame Larina's house, St. Petersburg, Russia, late 1700s
range: G3 to G4. Tessitura G3 to E4
synopsis: During a party for Tatiana's birthday, Triquet sings a song in honor of Tatiana.

title: Lensky's Aria (Kuda, kuda v udalilis)
subtitle: - from Act II, Scene 2 of the Russian opera, Eugene Onegin by Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky
libretto: Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky and Konstantin Shilovsky ,  after Pushkin's poem
role: Lensky,  fiance of Olga and friend of Onegin

range: E3 to G#/Ab4. Tessitura F3 to G4
synopsis: The night before, Lensky challenged Onegin to a duel in response to Onegin's advances on Lensky's fiancee, Olga.  Now, on the morning of the duel, Lensky looks back on his happy youth as he waits for Onegin to arrive.  He realizes that he will probably die in the duel and that he does not particularly care if he does.  The only great loss in his death would be that he would never see Olga again.

title: Prince Gremin's Aria (Lyubvi fse vozrast pokorn)
subtitle: - from Act III, Scene 1 of the Russian opera, Eugene Onegin by Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky
libretto: Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky and Konstantin Shilovsky ,  after Pushkin's poem
setting: a fancy ballroom in a house in St. Petersburg, Russia, late 1700s
range: F#/Gb2 to D#/Eb4. Tessitura D3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Gremin explains to Onegin how Tatiana came into his life two years prior and filled his life with love and happiness.  She is now his wife and he continues to be completely happy.

title: Onegin's Arioso (Uzhel ta samaja Tatiana)
subtitle: - from Act III, Scene 1 of the Russian opera, Eugene Onegin by Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky
libretto: Peter Illyich Tchaikovsky and Konstantin Shilovsky ,  after Pushkin's poem
role: Eugene Onegin,  friend of Lensky with first name often spelled "Yevgeny"
setting: a fancy ballroom in a house in St. Petersburg, Russia, late 1700s
range: F3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura F3 to D4
synopsis: After spending years away from civilization after the duel in which he killed his friend Lensky, Onegin attends a ball in St. Petersburg.  He sees Tatiana once more but, to his surprise, she is happily married.  Remembering how he rejected her love in the past, he realizes the true extent of his feelings for her.  He expresses the deep love for her that he has found inside himself and the sorrow that he feels because he has lost his chance.

title: L'onore! Ladri!
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Falstaff by Giuseppe Verdi
libretto: Arrigo Boito ,  based on Shakespeare's The Merry Wives of Windsor and Henry IV
role: Sir John Falstaff,  a fat knight
setting: Inside the Garter Inn, Windsor, England, early 15th century
range: G#/Ab2 to G4. Tessitura D3 to E4
synopsis: After the shiftless Bardolph and Pistol surprisingly refuse to help Falstaff trick Mistress Ford and Mistress Page out of their money because of their "honor", Falstaff lectures them of the meaningless of "honor".  Honor, he says, is nothing but a word.  It means nothing after life is over and cannot heal broken bones or wounds.  He finally chases the two of them out of the inn.

title: sogno? o realt
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, Falstaff by Giuseppe Verdi
libretto: Arrigo Boito ,  based on Shakespeare's The Merry Wives of Windsor and Henry IV
setting: Inside the Garter Inn, Windsor, England, early 15th century
range: A#/Bb3 to G4. Tessitura C3 to D#/Eb4
synopsis: Ford has been alerted to Falstaff's plan to seduce his wife.  He dresses in disguise and offers Falstaff money to help him seduce his own wife (although Falstaff doesn't know this because Ford is in disguise!).  When Falstaff tells him that he has already "made the acquaintance" of the lady and leaves him there, Ford becomes angry and worries about the possibility of his wife betraying their marriage vows and actually giving in to Falstaff's advances.

title: Quand'ero paggio del Duca di Norfolk

libretto: Arrigo Boito ,  based on Shakespeare's The Merry Wives of Windsor and Henry IV
role: Sir John Falstaff,  a fat knight

synopsis: When Dame Quickly tells Falstaff that both Mistress Page and Mistress Ford are in love with him, he rejoices with self-satisfaction.

title: Avant de quitter ces lieux

He is, however, worried because there will no one protect his sister while he is gone.  He asks God to take care of her while he fights.  He declares that he shall fight valiantly for his country and if he dies, he prays that he will be allowed to watch over his sister from Heaven.

His mother was later killed and his sister was taken.  Later on, Siegmund also lost his father and is now wandering through the countryside.  Some time ago, he attacked and killed a group of men trying to take a woman against her will.   Little does he know that Hunding's wife Sieglinde is really his long-lost sister or that Hunding's relatives were a part of the group of men that he killed.

title: Ein Schwert verhie mir der Vater
subtitle: from Act I, Scene 3 of the German opera, Die Walkre by Richard Wagner

Afterwards, he encourages the Roman citizens to reinstitute Rome's freedom from tyranny by passionately reminding them of the old tradition of Roman freedom.

title: Ich sah die Stdte

However, Adriano's loyalty is torn because he is also in love with Rienzi's daughter, Irene.  He asks God how he can reconcile the differences between his father and Rienzi and hopes that in the end, all will be resolved.

title: Allmcht'ger Vater (Rienzi's Prayer)

On the brink of disaster, Rienzi prays to God that he might be given strength to weather the crisis.  He feels that he is doing God's work by empowering the common citizen.

title: Ich liebte glhend meine hohe Braut
subtitle: - No. 14, Cavatine from Act V of the German opera, Rienzi by Richard Wagner
setting: a hall in the Capitol of Rome, Italy, middle of the 14th century

synopsis: Rienzi has been excommunicated and reviled for attempting to free Rome from the bonds of the tyranny of the nobles.  Meanwhile, his sister Irene is in love with one of the nobles.  When she implies that he does not understand her because he has never been in love, he replies that he has loved Rome, which is like a woman to him.  However, he now sees Rome falling to pieces around him and he is filled with sorrow.

subtitle: from Act I, Scene II of the Italian opera, Rigoletto by Giuseppe Verdi

title: Risorto fra le tenebre
subtitle: - Cabaletta for Un Inca, eccesso orribile from Prologue of the Italian opera, Alzira by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Zamoro,  the head of a Peruvian tribethe head of a Peruvian tribe
setting: A vast plain, Peru, mid-16th century
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Zamoro has returned from being captured by the Governor of Peru, Gusmano, and his troops.  His tribesmen are surprised to see him alive, thinking that he had been killed by Gusmano's torture.  After he rails against the injustice that Gusmano has caused him and his people, his tribesmen tell him that Alzira and her father Ataliba, another tribal head, have been taken prisoner by Gusmano.  Zamoro resolves to save them from the governor's cruel hands.  He then launches in this cabaletta, describing the rebellious air that has been pervading his people.

title: Eterna la memoria

title: Da Gusman sul fragil barca

The Count has discovered Figaro flirting with a woman he thinks is the Countess (really Susanna dressed as the Countess) and calls everyone around in a fury to witness her  shaming.  Everyone begs pardon for the offenders, but this only infuriates the Count further; until his real wife emerges and reveals the trickery of the past three acts, which finally shames him into begging her forgiveness. Susanna has just been beating Figaro roundly because of his teasing courtship of her in her disguise as the Countess.  Now he tells her lovingly, "Peace...I recognised the voice that I adore", and she replies in kind.  The Counts voice is heard off-stage.  He has lost his Susanna, really the Countess in disguise; Susanna and Figaro immediately resume their play-acting to provoke him further.  Figaro goes down on one knee to extravagantly woo the Countess, and, being sure that the Count sees them, they start to go off towards one of the arbours to "replace pain with pleasure".

	Voice Parts : baritone, soprano, tenor, mezzo-soprano   Fachs : Rigoletto - dramatic baritone, Gilda - lyric coloratura, Duke - lyric tenor, Maddalena - dramatic mezzo	Synopsis : While Rigoletto anticipates the vengeance that he has planned against the Duke for seducing his daughter, the Duke attempts to make another conquest by wooing Maddalena.  Maddalena responds with her belief that all he really wants is her body.  Gilda meanwhile despairs over what the Duke has done to her.
performed_by: Rigoletto (a hunchbacked jester), Gilda (Rigoletto's daughter), the Duke of Mantua, and Maddalena (sister of Sparafucile the assassin and infatuated with the Duke)
fachs: Rigoletto - dramatic baritone, Gilda - lyric coloratura, Duke - lyric tenor, Maddalena - dramatic mezzo
synopsis: While Rigoletto anticipates the vengeance that he has planned against the Duke for seducing his daughter, the Duke attempts to make another conquest by wooing Maddalena.  Maddalena responds with her belief that all he really wants is her body.  Gilda meanwhile despairs over what the Duke has done to her.

title: Tu non sai conquei begli occhi
subtitle: - No. 6, Cabaletta to Vi ravviso, o luoghi ameni from Act I of the Italian opera, La Sonnambula by Vincenzo Bellini
role: Count Rodolfo,  Lord of the village
setting: The village green of a village in Switzerland, early 19th century
range: C3 to D#/Eb4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to C#/Db4
synopsis: Count Rodolfo has come in disguise to stay a night at Lisa's inn.  He sees Amina and tells her of her beauty and how she reminds him of his youth.

title: Ah! perch non posso odiarti
subtitle: - No. 11 from Act II, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, La Sonnambula by Vincenzo Bellini
setting: A shady valley between the village and the castle, Switzerland, early 19th century
range: F3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura F3 to G4
synopsis: Elvino is angry with Amina because he caught her in Rodolfo's bedroom asleep.  Even though Rodolfo was not in the room and even though Amina arrived to the room via sleepwalking, he believes that she was there to sleep with another man.  Elvino has now met Amina and takes the ring he gave her back.  He knows that she loves him and that he loves her.  He can't figure out why she was in another room though.  He sings of these mixed feelings.

title: De' lieti auguri a voi
subtitle: - No. 12 from Act II, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, La Sonnambula by Vincenzo Bellini
role: Lisa,  an inn-keeper who is in love with Elvino
setting: Near the mill in a Swiss village, early 19th century
range: F4 to C6. Tessitura A5 to A6
synopsis: Lisa has convinced Elvino to marry her instead of his love, Amina, who  he thinks is unfaithful to him.  The villagers greet her and give her their best wishes.  She sings her thanks to them, saying that the love she received from them will never leave her.

title: Ah! non credea mirarti
subtitle: - Part of No. 14 from Act II, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, La Sonnambula by Vincenzo Bellini
role: Amina,  an orphan who has been adopted by Teresa
setting: Near the mill in a Swiss village, early 19th century
range: E4 to A6. Tessitura A5 to G5
synopsis: While sleepwalking, Amina prays for Elvino and then sings her sorrow.  She remembers the engagement ring that he took from her when he believed she was unfaithful to him.

title: Ah! non giunge uman pensiero
subtitle: - Part of No. 14 from Act II, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, La Sonnambula by Vincenzo Bellini
role: Amina,  an orphan who has been adopted by Teresa
setting: Near the mill in a Swiss village, early 19th century
range: F4 to D#/Eb6. Tessitura A#/Bb5 to G5
synopsis: After awaking from a sleepwalking episode to find that her love Elvino has decided that she was not unfaithful to him after all, Amina sings of her dissipating sorrow, blown away by Elvino's love.

title: Ah, fors'  lui...Sempre libera
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Traviata by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Violetta Valery,  a beautiful and wealthy Parisian
setting: A salon in the house of Violetta after a big party
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: The first part of this aria is taken up by Violetta musing over the offer of Alfredo's love and if he is her true love after her numerous flings.  In the second part, she decides not to worry about her problems and, instead, live only for pleasure and freedom.

title: Addio del passato
subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, La Traviata by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Violetta Valery,  a beautiful and wealthy Parisian
setting: Violetta's bedroom
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Violetta is now poor and about to die.  She receives a letter from Alfredo's father saying that Alfredo has discovered why she lied about her love for him and is coming to her.  She knows that it is too late, though, and sings a farewell to her happiness with Alfredo.

title: The "Brindisi" or "Drinking Song"(Libiamo ne' lieti calici)
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Traviata by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Alfredo Germont,  a young man in love with Violetta
setting: A late-night party at the house of Violetta Valery
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Alfredo is convinced by Gastone and Violetta to show off his voice.  He sings (as this title suggests) a drinking song.

title: De' miei bollenti spiriti
subtitle: from Act II of the Italian opera, La Traviata by Giuseppe Verdi
role: Alfredo Germont,  a young man in love with Violetta
setting: Violetta's country house
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Alfredo and Violetta have moved in together.  Alfredo sings of his happiness from living with her and of how much she loves him.

title: Di Provenza il mar
subtitle: from Act II of the Italian opera, La Traviata by Giuseppe Verdi
setting: Violetta's country house
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Alfredo's father has convinced Violetta that it is better for everyone if she leaves Alfredo.  She begs him to love her and then sneaks out of the house.  Later, a servant brings him her farewell letter and he rushes off to find her.  Giorgio stops him though  and sings this aria to remind him of their home in Provence and to ask him to return with him.

title: Un di, verso il Murzoll
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Wally by Alfredo Catalani
setting: The main square of Hochstoff, Switzerland, 19th century
range: D4 to B6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Walter has come to try to find Wally.  He wishes to sing with her but when he cannot find her, he sings by himself.  The song he sings is the song of the Edelweiss and it is composed by Wally.  It tells the tale of a girl who was killed by an avalanche and lives on as a flower.

title: Non  l'oro
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Wally by Alfredo Catalani
role: Giuseppe Hagenbach,  a popular hunter from Slden
setting: The main square of Hochstoff, Switzerland, 19th century
range: E3 to A5. Tessitura G#/Ab3 to G#/Ab4
synopsis: Hagenbach arrives in Hochstoff with a group of friends.  When asked by Stromminger, he arrogantly tells the tell of how he killed a bear with one single shot to the heart.

title: Ebben? Ne andr lontana
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Wally by Alfredo Catalani
setting: The main square of Hochstoff, Switzerland, 19th century
range: E4 to B6. Tessitura E4 to G5
synopsis: Wally is in love with Hagenbach.  However, her father does not like Hagenbach and wants her to marry his own friend Gellner.  He gives her an ultimatum marry instead Gellner or leave the house.  When faced with the decision, Wally decides that she must leave.  She despairs that she will never see her house again but she knows that she must be firm.

title: N mai dunque avr pace?
subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, La Wally by Alfredo Catalani
setting: Wally's room, Hochstoff, Switzerland, 19th century
range: D4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Wally is angry at Hagenbach because he has kissed her and she believes that he only kissed her to see if he could conquer her.  She swears to get revenge on him, regretting that her youthful innocence was taken by this man.

title: Pourquoi?
subtitle: from Act I of the French opera, Lakm by Leo Delibes
setting: A garden surrounding a secret temple in India
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Lakmé notices that the world seems different and she wonders why.

title: Bell Song ("Ou va la jeune Hindoue?")
subtitle: from Act II of the French opera, Lakm by Leo Delibes
setting: A public square in a town in India
range: E4 to E6. Tessitura Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Ordered by her father, Lakmé sings the legend of the pariah's daughter.  The girl was walking through the forest at night and comes upon a stranger who has been set upon by wild animals.  She rings a magic bell that is on her wand and saves the man, who is actually Vishnu, the son of Brahma the Creator.  Vishnu takes her up to paradise for saving him.

title: Tu m'as donne le plus doux reve
subtitle: from Act III of the French opera, Lakm by Leo Delibes
setting: A garden surrounding a secret temple in India
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Without Gerald knowing, Lakmé bites into a poisonous datura leaf because Gerald is leaving her.  Before she shows any signs of the poison, though, she tells him that she has learned much from him and offers the sacred cup to him to join them together eternally.

title: Fantaisie aux divins mensonges
subtitle: from Act I of the French opera, Lakm by Leo Delibes
role: Grald,  an officer in the British Army
setting: A garden surrounding a secret temple in India
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Left alone by his friends, Gerald sings of Lakmé, a priestess at the temple.  He imagines that she is there.

title: Ah! viens, dans la foret profonde
subtitle: from Act III of the French opera, Lakm by Leo Delibes
role: Grald,  an officer in the British Army
setting: A garden surrounding a secret temple in India
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After being attacked and nearly killed by the followers of Lakmé's father, Gerald sings that love has taken them away to a world of their own.

title: Qu' autour de moi toute sombre
subtitle: from Act III of the French opera, Lakm by Leo Delibes
role: Grald,  an officer in the British Army
setting: A garden surrounding a secret temple in India
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After joining their souls together for eternity by drinking from the sacred cup together, Gerald tells Lakmé that he never wants her to be sorrowful.  Little does he know that she has actually poisoned herself by eating a poisonous datura leaf.

title: Se l'augellin sen fugge
subtitle: - No. 2 (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: C4 to G5. Tessitura E4 to F5
synopsis: Anchises tells Ramiro that, even though Arminda may not love him any more, Ramiro will be able to find another woman soon.  Ramiro responds with this aria, singing that, like a bird who escapes from a cage, he will not return to that sort of imprisonment soon.

title: Noi donne poverine
subtitle: - No. 4 (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
role: Marchioness Violante Onesti,  in disguise as a gardener named Sandrina
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: F4 to A6. Tessitura A#/Bb5 to F5
synopsis: Anchises has just told Violante that he loves her.  She is rather disgusted by this, though, and thinks about leaving this job.  She sings her aria about the injustice that women face because men force themselves upon them.

title: Se promette facilmente
subtitle: - No. 7 (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: D#/Eb4 to A6. Tessitura E4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: After Belfiore declares his love to Arminda, she warns him to not to cheat on him.  Men, in her opinion, always promise to be faithful but they go out and betray them.  Arminda says if he tries the same trick on her, she will definitely get her revenge even if she does love him now.

title: Un marito, o dio
subtitle: - No. 9a, Arietta (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: E4 to D5. Tessitura E4 to D5
synopsis: Serpetta would like to marry soon and Roberto knows it.  He is trying to get her to marry him but she tells him that an old man like him is not right for her.

title: Appena mi vedon
subtitle: - No. 10 (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: D#/Eb4 to A6. Tessitura E4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Roberto would like to marry Serpetta.  She is sure that she could do better, though, and outlines the way she will get a husband in her aria.  She sings that men come to her as soon as they see her.  They expect that she will give into them but she just lets them go on their way.

title: Geme la tortorella
subtitle: - No. 11 (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
role: Marchioness Violante Onesti,  in disguise as a gardener named Sandrina
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: F#/Gb4 to C6. Tessitura A5 to A6
synopsis: Violante expresses her loneliness in this aria, comparing herself to a turtledove who is far from the nest.

title: Vorrei punirti indegno
subtitle: - No. 13 from Act II of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: a hall in Anchises's palace
range: D4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Arminda hears Belfiore mention Sandrina, the name his former love, Violante, is using for her disguise. This makes her very angry to hear this from him on their wedding day.  She sings that she would like to tear out his heart to punish him.  She restrains herself, though, because she loves him.  She cannot decide if she should be angry towards him or if she should forgive him.

title: Una voce sento al core
subtitle: - No. 16 from Act II of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
role: Marchioness Violante Onesti,  in disguise as a gardener named Sandrina
setting: a hall in Anchises's palace
range: E4 to A6. Tessitura A5 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: After reprimanding Anchises for being insulting towards her, she realizes that it might not have been such a good idea.  She blames in on herself.  To try and make him forgive her, she sings this aria.  She says that her heart is telling her that Anchises is good although he may appear to scorn her.  She sings that his anger towards her has made her sad and she asks all maidens who see her to console her for her sorry fate.

title: Dolce d'amor compagna speranza
subtitle: - No. 18 from Act II of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: a hall in Anchises's palace
range: D4 to G5. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Ramiro tries to approach Arminda and speak to her, but she will have nothing to do with her and leaves him.  He has not given up though and declares in his aria that he still has hope and that hope will sustain him through all else.

title: Chi vuol godere il mondo
subtitle: - No. 20 from Act II of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: a hall in Anchises's palace
range: D4 to G5. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Serpetta tells Roberto in this aria that he should not push her so much into loving her.  She knows that she should be sincere and cheerful but that doesn't work today with men.  The only thing to do is to pretend to be shy and make excuses to make the men long for you.  She then finishes the aria by saying that she learned this from her mother.

title: Crudeli, fermate
subtitle: - No. 21 from Act II of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
role: Marchioness Violante Onesti,  in disguise as a gardener named Sandrina
setting: a dark deserted cave
range: D#/Eb4 to G#/Ab5. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Violante has been abducted and left in a dark cave alone.  In her aria, she expresses her fear and anger at being left alone.  She asks the gods to help her.

title: Ah dal pianto
subtitle: - No. 22, Cavatina from Act II of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
role: Marchioness Violante Onesti,  in disguise as a gardener named Sandrina
setting: a dark deserted cave
range: G4 to C6. Tessitura B5 to F5
synopsis: After trying to find a way out of the cave she is in, Violante's grief sets in.  She sings that she cannot breathe because she is crying so much.  She has given up all chances to get out of this situation.

title: Va pure ad altri in braccio
subtitle: - No. 26 from Act III of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: the courtyard of Anchises's palace
range: D4 to G5. Tessitura G4 to F5
synopsis: Arminda tells Ramiro that he has no chance of getting her love and that he should just forget him.  She leaves him there alone.  He sings that she can go to some other man.  Even though he is deeply pained, he shall be hers until he dies.

title: Dentro il mio petto
subtitle: - No. 3 (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: D3 to G4. Tessitura F#/Gb3 to G4
synopsis: After he has told Sandrina of how he loves her, Anchises sings of the sound of the orchestra with its flutes and oboes and its drum and trumpets.  The mighty sound almost makes him mad.

title: Che belt, che leggiadria
subtitle: - No. 6 (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
role: Count Belfiore,  in love with Arminda
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: D3 to G4. Tessitura F3 to F4
synopsis: Belfiore arrives in a carriage and as he looks at a portrait of Arminda, praises her beauty and radiance.  He is also directly complimenting Arminda who is present during the entire aria.

title: Sirocco a tramontana
subtitle: - No. 8 (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
role: Count Belfiore,  in love with Arminda
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: C3 to G4. Tessitura E3 to E4
synopsis: In a failed attempt to impress Arminda, Belfiore recites his impressive lineage.  He wonders why Arminda begins to laugh at him though in the middle.  He believes that she should be bowing to her.

title: Care pupille
subtitle: - No. 15 from Act II of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
role: Count Belfiore,  in love with Arminda
setting: a hall in Anchises's palace
range: E3 to G4. Tessitura F3 to F4
synopsis: Violante, pretending to be Sandrina, tells Belfiore how rotten she heard he was from Violante as she lay dying.  She wants her to leave.  During the aria, he wants her to look at her, but she doesn't.  Finally, he gets ready to leave but asks to kiss her hand before he leaves.  Instead of kissing Violante's hand, he actually kisses the hand of Don Anchises who has come up next to her.  When Belfiore realizes this, he apologizes and then curses his bad luck.

title: Una damina, una nipote
subtitle: - No. 17 from Act II of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: a hall in Anchises's palace
range: C3 to G4. Tessitura F#/Gb3 to G4
synopsis: Arminda enters and declares that she has decided to marry Belfiore.  After her, though, comes Ramiro who has come to take Belfiore to jail for the alleged murder of Violante.  Anchises is concerned about this charge and, in his aria, declares that if her were to let his niece Arminda marry this man, he would become the ridicule of the whole world.  So, he declares that it will not happen.

title: Ah non partir...Gi divento freddo
subtitle: - No. 19 Recitative and Aria from Act II of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
role: Count Belfiore,  in love with Arminda
setting: a hall in Anchises's palace
range: D3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: Belfiore is questioned by Anchises about whether he killed Violante or not.  He begins to incriminate himself but Violante saves him.  She reveals that she is not Sandrina the garden maid, but really Marchioness Violante Onesti and, since she is there, he couldn't have killed her.  Arminda becomes jealous and leaves and Anchises, who was in love with Sandrina, also departs in a rage.  Belfiore is left alone with Violante, but she also leaves.  He attempts to stop her in the accompanied recitative but is unable to.  In the aria, he describes his cold and trembling unhappiness he feels.  Nearby, though, he feels a light breeze and he is able to see the sun in front of him.  There is some hope still.

title: Mio padrone, io dir volevo
subtitle: - No. 25 from Act III of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: the courtyard in Anchises's palace
range: D3 to G4. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: Everyone is arguing about who will marry who and Anchises tries to arbitrate.  His aria comprises of him trying to talk to all of them at once and ends up being uncomprehensible.

title: A forza di martelli
subtitle: - No. 5 (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: D3 to E4. Tessitura G3 to D4
synopsis: Roberto believes that he has the worst situation of any of the other characters.  He is attempting to win Serpetta, but  he believes that sculpting marble or forging iron is less difficult than taming a woman.  He wonders why men are such fools to even try.

title: Un marito, o dio
subtitle: - No. 9b, Arietta (original libretto lost, trans. from German) from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: the garden of Don Anchises
range: E3 to D4. Tessitura E3 to D4
synopsis: Roberto knows that Serpetta would like to marry soon and wants to marry a young man.  He tries to convince her that an older man like him is better than a young one.

title: Con un vezzo all'Italiana
subtitle: - No. 14 from Act II of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: a hall in Anchises's palace
range: E3 to E4. Tessitura E3 to E4
synopsis: Serpetta says that, if Roberto will sing her a love song, she will love him.  He sings her this multi-lingual aria which includes phrases of love in Italian, French, and English to try and impress her.  She is not impressed though and he becomes frustrated.

title: Mirate che constrasto
subtitle: from Act III of the Italian opera, La Finta Giardiniera by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
libretto: Raniero de Calzabigi ,  revised by Marco Coltellini
setting: the courtyard at Anchises's palace
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Violante and Belfiore have gone insane.  Violante thinks she is Herminea, Roberto's lover, and Belfiore believes that Roberto is Venus and tries to approach her amorously.  Roberto is very embarassed by all this and distracts them both in this aria by telling them to look at the heavens.

title: Troppa briga a prender moglie
subtitle: - No. 2 from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Semplice by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: Cassandro's house near Cremona
range: G2 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Simone grumbles that he isn't interested in marriage and all its sacrifices.

title: Marito io vorrei
subtitle: - No. 3 from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Semplice by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Giacinta,  the somewhat aged sister of Polidoro and Cassandro
setting: Cassandro's house near Cremona
range: C3 to F5. Tessitura G4 to E5
synopsis: Giacinta remarks that all she wants is a man of fidelity.  She has no need of passion.

title: Non c' al mondo
subtitle: - No. 4 from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Semplice by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: Cassandro's house near Cremona
range: A3 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Cassandro exclaims how the world is full of women.  He wishes they would all go away.

title: Guarda la donna in viso
subtitle: - No. 5 from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Semplice by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Fracasso,  a Hungarian captain staying with Cassandro
setting: Cassandro's house near Cremona
range: C3 to G4. Tessitura G3 to E4
synopsis: Fracasso explains to Cassandro that women have many charms and because of their beauty alone, it is worth it to keep them around.

title: Colla bocca e non col core
subtitle: - No. 6 from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Semplice by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: Cassandro's house near Cremona
range: D#/Eb4 to B6. Tessitura A5 to F5
synopsis: Rosina slyly comments that she can teach all women to make men appreciate them.

title: Cosa ha mai la donna indosso
subtitle: - No. 7 from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Semplice by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
role: Polidoro,  the timid brother of Cassandro and Giacinta
setting: Cassandro's house near Cremona
range: E3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura G3 to G4
synopsis: Polidoro states that every woman attracts him, even the ugly ones.

title: Ella vuole ed io torrei
subtitle: - No. 8 from Act I of the Italian opera, La Finta Semplice by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
setting: Cassandro's house near Cremona
range: C3 to D4. Tessitura C3 to C4

title: Senti l'eco ove t'aggiri

setting: Cassandro's house near Cremona
range: F4 to A6. Tessitura G4 to G5

range: F4 to G5. Tessitura F4 to F5

range: D4 to A6. Tessitura G4 to G5

range: A3 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4

range: D#/Eb4 to A6. Tessitura F#/Gb4 to F#/Gb5
synopsis: Alone, Rosina muses on Love and hopes that it will not torment her.

title: Ubriaco non son io

range: C3 to D4. Tessitura D3 to D4

range: E4 to A6. Tessitura G4 to G5
synopsis: Rosina tells Cassandro that a woman can only be content when she has many lovers.

range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: While the assembled crowd prays that the soldiers will be victorious over the Germans, Lida prays that Rolando can forgive her infidelity with Arrigo.

title: Mi chiamano Mimi

setting: Christmas Eve in a room in an attic
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After Rodolfo tells her that he has fallen in love with her, he asks Mimi to tell him something of her.  She responds, telling him (among other things) that her name is Lucia, although she is called Mimi.

title: Quando m'en vo'
subtitle: from Act II of the Italian opera, La Bohme by Giacomo Puccini
setting: The Cafe Momus
range: Has not been entered yet.

range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Rodolfo and Mimi have had a fight, Rodolfo saying that Mimi has been flirting with other men.  However, the real reason he wants to separate from Mimi is because she is very sick and he cannot bear to watch her die.  He reveals this to Marcello, but Mimi overhears him and, after Marcello leaves, she comes out to him and asks him to return all of her possessions to her former room.

title: Che gelida manina
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Bohme by Giacomo Puccini
setting: Christmas Eve in a room in an attic
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After both of their candles go out, Rodolfo and a young woman who has come to his room in order to relight her candle are in the darkness together.  Pretending to look for her key which she had lost in the room, Rodolfo instead finds her hand and sings to her of his dreams and ambitions.  He also tells her that he has fallen in love with her.

title: Vecchia zimarra
subtitle: from Act IV of the Italian opera, La Bohme by Giacomo Puccini
setting: An attic room
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: After Mimi has collapsed on the staircase to the attic room, she is carried into the room.  On the edge of death, she says that her hands are cold.  In order to buy her something to keep her hands warm, Musetta pawns her jewelry and Colline decides to pawn his old overcoat, to which he sings farewell.

title: Oh, come pochi sorsi
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Calisto by Francesco Cavalli

setting: a parched forest, Pelsgia, Peloponnese

In order to quench her thirst, Giove causes a spring to flow once more.  When Calisto comes across it, she rejoices in the sweet and satisfying water and in her own freedom.

title: Va pur, va pur, va seco
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Calisto by Francesco Cavalli

range: D3 to E4. Tessitura E3 to D4

range: D4 to G5. Tessitura G4 to F5

title: Amara servit
subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Calisto by Francesco Cavalli
role: Diana,  the Virgin Goddess of the hunt
setting: a parched forest, Pelsgia, Peloponnese
range: D4 to F5. Tessitura D4 to F5
synopsis: Diana ardently loves Endimione; but she suffers because of her vow of chastity.

subtitle: from Act I of the Italian opera, La Calisto by Francesco Cavalli

title: Ammirabili forme
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, La Calisto by Francesco Cavalli

title: Dalle gelose mie

range: C4 to A6. Tessitura E4 to E5

title: Miei rampolli femminini

title: Vasto teatro  il mondo
subtitle: - Cavatina, music actually composed by Luca Agolini from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, La Cenerentola by Gioacchino Rossini

range: D3 to E4. Tessitura E3 to E4
synopsis: Don Magnifico and his daughters have been invited to the Prince's ball.  Don Magnifico will not allow Cenerentola to go along, however.  After the rest of the family leaves, Cenerentola is left alone with Alidoro who is in disguise as one of the King's officials.  Alidoro realizes the goodness in Cenerentola and tells her that he will bring her to the ball himself.  She asks him if this is some sort of play and he responds with this aria, saying that the whole world is a stage.

title: L del ciel nell'arcano profondo
subtitle: - alternate aria written to take the place of "Vasto teatro e il mondo" from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, La Cenerentola by Gioacchino Rossini
role: Alidoro,  a philosopher and the tutor of Don Ramiro
setting: The mansion of Don Magnifico
range: Has not been entered yet.
synopsis: Don Magnifico and his daughters have been invited to the Prince's ball.  Don Magnifico will not allow Cenerentola to go along, however.  After the rest of the family leaves, Cenerentola is left alone with Alidoro who is in disguise as one of the King's officials.  Alidoro realizes the goodness in Cenerentola and tells her that he will bring her to the ball himself.  She believes that he is making fun of her.  To show her that he means what he says, he throws off his cloak to reveal his noble clothes beneath and sings to her that God himself has looked down upon her and shows favor upon her and thus, she should not be afraid of going to the ball.  He then goes on to say that his carriage is coming and, although she must be confused and upset, she will soon be in happier days.

title: Come un'ape ne'giorni d'aprile
subtitle: - Cavatina with Chorus from Act I, Scene 1 of the Italian opera, La Cenerentola by Gioacchino Rossini

synopsis: Dandini is disguised as his master, Prince Ramiro, in order to help his master investigate the marital possibilities at Don Magnifico's house.  He sings that, although he has hopped like a bee from "flower" to "flower", he cannot find a woman who is special enough to be his wife.  Meanwhile, he makes side remarks to Prince Ramiro (who is disguised as a courtier) about how well he is doing.

title: Intendente..reggitor?
subtitle: - Aria with Chorus from Act I, Scene 2 (sometimes performed at the beginning of the second act) of the Italian opera, La Cenerentola by Gioacchino Rossini
role: Don Magnifico,  baron of Monte Fiascone

range: B3 to E4. Tessitura D3 to D4
synopsis: Don Magnifico has amazed others with his drinking capacity enough so that he has been pronounced the Prince's new steward.  He decides that his first act of duty will be to write a proclamation banning the mixing of water and wine.

setting: The palace of the Prince
range: C3 to F4. Tessitura D3 to D4

They are still confident that one of them will win the Prince to the point that Don Magnifico believes he will be granted a high position of power in the Prince's retinue.  He acts out a meeting between a female petioner and himself playing both parts.

title: Udite, udite, o rustici

Confident because of his dose of "love potion" (which is really just wine), he ignores them as well as his love Adina.  Adina is hurt by this and leaves.  Nemorino notices her unhappiness and realizes that she does care for him.  He sings of his joy at finding that he is loved by her.

She comments that she is only in this danger because of her great love for Lindoro, but she goes on to state that the pirates are only men and therefore, no challenge to her wits.

title: Gi d'insolito ardore

Afterwards, Lindoro sings to her, telling her that now that she is here, he has found happiness again from his grief.

title: Ho un gran peso

title: Per lui che adoro

subtitle: - Cabaletta for Se al nuovo d pugnando from Act III, Scene 2 of the Italian opera, La Battaglia di Legnano by Giuseppe Verdi

title: J'ai la perdue!(Io l' ho perduta!)
subtitle: - From the 4-act version only from Act I (Act II in the 5 act version) of the Italian|French opera, Don Carlos by Giuseppe Verdi
libretto: Joseph Mry and Camille du Locle.  Translated into Italian by A. Ghislanzoni
role: Don Carlos,  heir to the throne of Spain
setting: The cloister of San Yuste, in Extremadura, 1559
range: D3 to A#/Bb5. Tessitura F3 to F#/Gb4
synopsis: Don Carlos wanders desperately while inside a chapel his father Philip is being married to the prince's fiance, Elizabeth of Valois.  He sings of his love.

title: Au palais des fes (Nei giardin del bello)
subtitle: - Chanson du Voile (Canzone del velo) from Act II (Act I in four-act version), Scene 2 of the Italian|French opera, Don Carlos by Giuseppe Verdi
libretto: Joseph Mry and Camille du Locle
role: Princess Eboli,  lady in waiting to the Queen of Spain
setting: At the gates of the cloisters of St-Just Monastery, Madrid, Spain, 1559
range: D4 to A6. Tessitura E4 to E5
synopsis: Eboli sings a Moorish love song about an encounter between a young veiled woman and the King who has tired of the Queen's attention.  It is only at the end of the song that the King finds out the veiled woman is actually the Queen herself.

title: L'Infant Carlos, notre esprance (Carlo ch' sol il nostro amore)
subtitle: - Romance from Act II (Act I in four-act version), Scene 2 of the Italian|French opera, Don Carlos by Giuseppe Verdi
libretto: Joseph Mry and Camille du Locle
setting: At the gates of the cloisters of St-Just Monastery, Madrid, Spain, 1559
range: C#/Db3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura D#/Eb3 to D4
synopsis: Rodrigo tells Elizabeth of the emotional pain Carlos has been through recently.  Carlos, who was in love with Elizabeth when she was forced to marry Carlos's father, has been in misery since the marriage.  Rodrigo says that Carlos's spirits would be greatly improved if he could see her again.

title: Oh ma chre compagne (Non pianger, mia compagna)
subtitle: - Romance from Act II (Act I in four-act version), Scene 2 of the Italian|French opera, Don Carlos by Giuseppe Verdi
libretto: Joseph Mry and Camille du Locle
role: Elisabeth of Valois,  Queen of Spain
setting: At the gates of the cloisters of St-Just Monastery, Madrid, Spain, 1559
range: C4 to A#/Bb6. Tessitura F4 to A6
synopsis: After Philip has sent the Countess Aremberg away for leaving the Queen unattended, Elizabeth tells her that even though she is leaving Spain, she will never leave her heart.  She asks the Countess to give her greetings to the Queen's homeland of France.  She then gives her a parting present of a ring.

title: Elle ne m'aime pas (Ella giammai m'am)
subtitle: from Act IV (Act III in four-act version), Scene 1 of the Italian|French opera, Don Carlos by Giuseppe Verdi
libretto: Joseph Mry and Camille du Locle
role: Philip II,  The King of Spain
setting: The King's cabinet, Madrid, Spain, 1559
range: F#/Gb2 to E4. Tessitura A3 to D4
synopsis: Philip realizes that his wife has never loved him and will never love him.  He wishes that he could read the minds of others.  Alas, though, the crown does not allow him this power and he will only be at peace when he dies.

title: O don fatale (O don fatal)
subtitle: from Act IV (Act III in four-act version), Scene 1 of the Italian|French opera, Don Carlos by Giuseppe Verdi
libretto: Joseph Mry and Camille du Locle
role: Princess Eboli,  lady in waiting to the Queen of Spain
setting: The King's cabinet, Madrid, Spain, 1559
range: B4 to B6. Tessitura D#/Eb4 to G#/Ab5
synopsis: Eboli has betrayed her Queen and friend Elizabeth to the Queen because her advances to Carlos have been rejected.  In retaliation, Elizabeth gives her the choice of being exiled or becoming a nun.  After she leaves, Eboli curses the gift of beauty that she has been given, saying that it has been the cause of all her problems.  She swears to save Carlos from the imprisonment that has resulted from her betrayal.

title: C'est mon jour suprme (Per me giunto  il di supreme)
subtitle: - Romance from Act IV (Act III in four-act version), Scene 2 of the Italian|French opera, Don Carlos by Giuseppe Verdi
libretto: Joseph Mry and Camille du Locle
setting: The prison cell of Carlos, Madrid, Spain, 1559
range: C3 to F4. Tessitura E3 to F4
synopsis: Rodrigo has planned to save Carlos from his sentence of death for treason by confessing falsely to having committed the treason himself, thus proving Carlos innocent.  He knows that he will be killed, but he does not mind laying his life down for Carlos.  He asks Carlos not to mourn for him, for God will see them both reunited in Heaven.

title: Ah, je meurs, l'me joyeuse (Io morr, ma lieto in core)
subtitle: - Romance from Act IV (Act III in four-act version), Scene 2 of the Italian|French opera, Don Carlos by Giuseppe Verdi

range: E3 to F#/Gb4. Tessitura F3 to F#/Gb4

She admonishes the other children present that they should follow Albert's example and resist the temptations that come upon them.  At the end of her speech, she loses her notes and finishes with several aborted patriotic sayings.

title: Albert the Good
subtitle: from Act II, Scene 2 of the English opera, Albert Herring by Benjamin Britten

setting: Mrs Herring's greengrocery, Loxford, East Suffock, England, the night of May first, 1900

synopsis: At the party at which he is named King of May as a testament to his virtuous behavior, Albert discovers the joys of alcohol.  After the party, he revels in the joyous food and drinks of which he partook.  He especially enjoyed the lemonade that was spiked with rum, unbeknownst to him.  His thoughts shift to Nancy, who was with him at the celebration.  He wonders why she paid so much attention to him at the party.  He doesn't think that she could be interested in him because he is shy and no girl could really like him.  The mere thought of a girl liking him sends him floating on a cloud of ecstasy.

title: I can't remember everything
subtitle: from Act III of the English opera, Albert Herring by Benjamin Britten
role: Albert Herring,  clerk in his mother's grocery store

He finally shows up and, when asked where he was, replies that he stayed out all night.  He says that he decided that it was time he experienced some of the more sinful parts of life.  He explains that he went to several pubs and got roaring drunk and eventually got into a fight.  He finishes it all by explaining that he did it because of the unrealistic expectations of virtue that his mother and the town had of him.

title: What would Missus Herring say?
